Review Text: Had a return train journey booked pre floods to Kandy for 3 days. Given the floods I kept and eye on updates and their website. Also checked with plantation stay we had planned. The train couldn’t reach Kandy but the stop prior . That was ok for us as the hotel said they would pick us up from there. The hotel and I kept checking with the railway and the website right up to 6 hours pre departure. On arrival at the station we were informed that the trains were cancelled due to line work ! We could have got the 4am train and we could get the one at 2pm . Was told at first that the website I looked at was fake! Pointed out that it was the same site I booked and received my tickets from! Then told that they don’t update the website! Welcome to the 21st century. The still manager seemed to find it all very funny. sitting there grinning at me. What’s more the hotel informed me that tickets were still available to buy for that trip!  The railway set up is a shambles , we had looked forward to this rail trip and one of the main reasons for visiting Sri Lanka. I understand floods can’t be helped but giving false and misleading information can. We ended up having to do the the 3hr trip by taxi. The farce didn’t end there . Another trip to Galle was booked (1st class not available ) . We booked 2nd class which should have guaranteed a seat , yeah right ! Might just as well spat in the wind. Still they carried on selling 2nd class tickets . Don’t bother with the toilets either , a hole in the floor to the tracks! We travelled rail in so many countries , this is without doubt the worst. Also beware of scammers on these  journeys waiting to pounce on unsuspecting travellers to lead them on to other scammers at the destination .. they work as teams .
Beautiful building still actively used since the mid 1800’s. Building itself is nice but operation is crowded and feels chaotic. Kinda dirty.
Quaint, clean, no rush and transport easily available at the gates. So convenient for travellers coming in. Trains coming in at the correct time and leaving at the correct time. Good for commuters.
Wash rooms are not repairing. Unclean and very dirty.  So many passengers coming to fort railway station every day. It is very bad situation

Beautiful building but bit grubby.  It is chaotic.  If you already have your tickets (purchased online) you can enter at the back entrance which our accommodation dropped us to, it is not as busy but there are stairs to cross over the train lines, so if you are carrying heavy baggage with you this can be hard going.  It was quite hard finding where the train would depart from and where we needed to stand.  A station worker came along before the train arrived asking to see tickets and directed us to the other end of the platform for boarding.  Getting on the train is quite busy and you need to be able to lift your own bags up train steps although some people did help out.  The seats assigned were not that hard to find.  We did the trip to Galle along the coast and it was really pleasant.  The doors on our carriage were locked and they didn't allow people to walk through.  There were a couple of people coming through selling drinks and food but we had already got snacks and drinks with us so didn't need anything.  The right hand side of the train had the best views of the coast but you can still see on the other side.  Glad we had booked first class tickets so we had a seat as the train was packed by the time it arrived at fort station.  Can't purchase 2nd class tickets for this stretch ahead of time.

Review Title: Worst experience unsafe experience of colombo to Kandy train
Review Text: Very poor experience if you want to experience jumps opt for this .... I booked observation class and too hot .... Must say they should learn to modify their train facility .. Not recommend for pregnant ladies not safe very poor I will say worst service.

I went early in the morning to go to the finish line. She was alone, anxious in the early morning when it was still dark. A man approached us and told us that he wanted to buy a ticket to the finish line. When I felt like I should stay away from him, he opened the zipper on my body bag. My wallet, which was jabbered, I couldn't slurp, but it was a hiccup because I also had my passport in it. We were giving out free milk tea on the station platform, but when I asked if it was free, they said how much. When I didn't get it, a woman nearby told me to drink it because it was free and it was delicious. Urban stations require caution. A photo was also taken of Japanese people, perhaps because they are rare. It's been a lot, but it's been a good experience.

Review Title: A must visit Crazy Place if you are travelling in Sri Lanka
Review Text: We visited to try and get some advance  reserved seats on the Colombo to Badulla train, but of course there were none. All bought by tour operators. We then waited in the station to get a train from Colombo to Kurunegala. The station was manic, facilities weren’t great but it was efficient. We also were helped to our train, which was 3rd class, slow and stopped at every station. A real experience.

Colombo Central Station has remained what it once was. It's a white building, colonial style; inside a good number of lines but not many and united sidewalks knows overpasses, certainly not suitable for those with reduced mobility. The ticket office and information office work well and provide the required directions.

Review Title: please dont use the train from colombo to kandy , book  a car. Old unmaintained trains. toilets dirty even in first clas
Review Text: the train from fort col to kandy at 10:00 am was the worst journey ever. at every halt jerk, (booked first class), no water

It's amazing during rush hour on weekdays, but after that people are sparse. A relaxing atmosphere is ◎ Fort station was checking? (collecting?) tickets at the exit, so don't lose them. I struggled to get in and out at first, as I couldn't see it at the entrance. 笑 Train ride in the Indian Ocean wind, awesome~ I thought it might be a good idea to take a few stops to get to the nearest area.

Drop off in front of the station, 10 platforms, and several matrix signs with departure information. Multiple small vendors, benches to sit on the platforms, and free of charge toilets spotted at platform 1 (I didn't check them out, do no idea of the state).

We got there to get tickets and ended at the tourist information center. Prassana there got us the tickets and recommendations for the trip we planned. He offered us a private driver and, even though it was for us an unexpected expense, it really was the best idea. The driver, Terence, guided us through part of the trip with experience and cordiality. We avoided long hours of transport and made the best of our trip. Terence took us to everywhere and gave us local recommendations, and was a great way to know the country from a local view. Probably not the best option for everyone, but I would undoubtedly recommend it to anyone. Thanks to Terence for everything, we will contact him again if we are lucky enough to be back.

Great British station we used to do the best about 5 platforms toilets food drinks wide platforms lots of seats but remember if you get up come back it will be gone lots of beggars it's there pitch don't let it bother you give if you want to but not if you don't the locals feel compelled try the station if you are a railway buff

Due to major rail replacement work that commenced in January 2024 and is expected to last for six months, there are currently no trains running from Colombo to Jaffna. Although the main train website is supposed to provide updated information, it continues to show live running trains daily, which is misleading. Train companies need to promptly update their website with accurate and current information. I only learned about the disruption after visiting the Colombo Fort main station and inquiring in person, highlighting the necessity for better communication to avoid inconvenience for passengers.

This is an old-style railway station with nine platforms. There are separate toilets (accessible by key) for foreigners.  The male 'general' public toilets weren't spotless, but they were far from the worst I've seen in Asia. The station can be very busy as hordes of commuters use it. Long distance trips such as to Badulla or (shorter) Kandy are extremely scenic.  Fares are cheap, and some trains have openable windows that are preferable to air conditioned carriages. There are some shops, and provided one takes the usual precautions with smartphones and wallets/purses/bags, the station area is safe. Staff are helpful though the level of English proficiency varies.

This train station is located near the Pettah Market where I could walk from. Traffic was terrible and crossing the street is another story so I decided to ride a tuktuk. There are windows here where I was able to buy my round trip train tickets for Kandy. It has some shops to buy snacks, public toilets and few benches to sit down while waiting for the train. Lots of locals use it for their daily commutes. Interesting to watch passengers boarding and getting off the trains here. There are staff to ask here about the correct tracks and train cars to board.

The information center offers no real support. Some of the travel suggestions are bad-mouthed and attempts are made to sell a complete travel package including driver and accommodation. For example, we had pre-booked accommodation (Trincomalee) and this was dismissed as a very bad idea. (Monsoon, sea dangerous and the train from there to Habarana only 3rd class with standing room and completely overcrowded) The reality was: Wonderful weather and sea in Trincomalee and the train (we are currently traveling in) 2nd class relatively empty and comfortable. Our other travel ideas were dismissed in the same way. Luckily we did not accept the offer and organized ourselves as planned.

The station is very old and not maintained well, poor management,especially the toilets are disgusting, can not go inside as it’s smell so bad can’t beeath when inside, next platform also the air polluted by the bad smell in toilets,please do  something to go beyond this terrible situation,, Thank you

They sold us and hundred others tickets when train was full (even corridors). Train came 1 hour late and we went an hour before so we lost: train tickets money 3 tuk tuk ride money (we visited station previous day but they didnt wamt to sell us ticket in advance) taxi in black market 18000 lkr

It took me around 45 mins to get to the station from CMB airport. I booked the ticket in advance, The staff and conductors of the station were friendly and helpful, the train moved exactly at the time stated in the ticket but it arrived at the destination around 1 hour late than that was it supposed to. I took the Colombo Fort-Habarana train. The train is a great way to enjoy the green beautiful sceneries of Sri Lanka, tickets are cheap but booking through 3rd part website makes it like x3 times more expensive. Train is not really suitable If you have an oversized luggage, It will be hard moving through corridors. And Don’t expect luxury trains.

Old, dilapidated, worn-out train station. Busy and chaotic.  Not nearly as cared for as the small stations in rural areas which are beautifully decorated with planter boxes, some with koi ponds. Here’s a tip….as of Nov 2023, a tuk-tuk to the Zest Metropole or Fairway in the old fort area should cost two hundred rupees.

The local train is a smart way to travel within Colombo, especially when one is not pressed for time. The Colombo Fort station is located next to the Pettah market and is walking distance from the Port area as well.

The Colombo Fort Railway station is in Olcott Mawatha Road and a major rail hub in Colombo. It is the main rail station to central Colombo and the terminus of most intercity trains; and served by Sri Lanka Railways. The present station was opened in 1917,constructed similar to Manchester Victoria station Britain and built on land reclaimed from the beira Lake.

I was expecting a busy and hectic train station in the Indian style, but it wasn't. Nice experience but was it because it was Sunday? I had purchased a ticket in advance for 1st class and it was easy to find my departure platform on the screen. The conductor helped to find the right carriage. I don't recommend taking a large suitcase because it won't fit on the sled above your seat, tho if necessary, the conductor can help move large bags to a different carriage.

Not sure why this is a point of interest/landmark. I would avoid this place if you can. The train is one of the best things to do in Sri Lanka BUT the Fort is VERY busy and chaotic because of 3rd class passengers fighting for a spot on the train and tuktuk traffic outside the station. If you can get off the train before this station or get on form a different location with a second class ticket I would recommend that

I have never been to India, but this is how I imagine those overly crowded places full of people pushing in each direction, bumping into each other and forming crowds pushing themselves out of the building. I sincerely didn't notice anything about the architecture. If this place has any historical value, which I assume it does, I didn't pay any attention. All I did was to get of my train, then I looked around, and then I pushed myself with a mass of other people that were pushing themselves to the exit. If you want to keep a memory of your train ticket, take a picture of it. You will need to give it at the exit to the train station's personnel that is collecting the train tickets from people leaving the train station. Outside part of the train station is another nightmare. Full of tuk tuk and taxi drivers, you won't have a minute of peace to check e.g. map, orientate yourself or plan you next steps. When you cross the street, there is bunch of stands selling bunch of useless things that you don't need and you are just pushing yourself also through that. You will end up at a local market where it's, surprisingly, also crowded. My advice, get out as soon as possible. For me, this was the worst train station that I had experienced at Sri Lanka.

If you don’t have train tickets I’d recommend you purchase tickets as soon as you arrive in Sri Lanka. You can purchase tickets for train travel in the future. The ticket lines can be a bit chaotic but hold your place in line.

The station is hectic but no where near as India. Ground staff are most helpful helping us with our luggage into the cabin and locating our seat. Ticket office needs improvement to reduce waiting times, would be great to buy tickets online; maybe there is a way but we couldn’t give a way

Important advice - get here with plentyof time to spare!  There are people everywhere, trains coming and going, bewildered tourists wandering around, locals cramming ontop carriages and no signs or announcements which platifrm your train departs from.  You need to find someone official looking in a uniform and ask which platform your train leaves from and then probably get a second opinion!  As I said, a great travel experience.

We took the train from Weligama to Colombo.   It was a terrible 4-hour journey.  We were not prepared for the trains to be that crowded.  We didn't have place to even stand properly, let alone keep our baggage.  It was very claustrophobic.  I would have rather spent the 8K on an AC cab than take the train, had I known it was going to be so bad. We arrived at Colombo station, and from there we were told we could take a tuk tuk to the airport.   Being a fairly large station, I expected some sort of organization, but there was no pre-paid taxi or tuk-tuk stand, and the guy at the inquiry counter was busy on the phone and just ignored me.  The tuk-tuk drivers at the stand follow you around n quote ridiculous prices.  They quoted between 3K and 4K to the airport which is about 34 kms away.  We obviously thought that was too much and started walking a little further in an attempt to wave down a passing tuk-tuk, but the drivers follow you around and harass you.  The minute you flag down a tuk-tuk, they start speaking in the local language and telling the driver how much to ask for.  At one point, one of these drivers following us went and sat in one of the tuk-tuks we had stopped n started arguing with that driver because he was stealing his customers. Luckily, in the end, after walking about 100 mts, we managed to get a really nice guy who charged us by the meter.  We even gladly paid him extra, and he was very happy.

I had a trip from Colombo to Kandy. It was pre booked. Train arrived on time and had a wonderful & safe journey. Gate ticket checker was polite and willing to give directions . But inside the station was not properly maintained, managed. Toilets were disappointing. Food stalls were really busy and they didn’t care about their customers. I bought 02 no’s of vegetable roti from one of stalls which was close to platform 02. I was so disappointed to say one vegetable roti was spoiled.Both had different fillings as well.I brought that matter to stall owner, it seemed he didn’t care. All they need money and they have an enough flow of customers.May be that might be the reason.Please stop selling spoiled foods. Kind enough to give value for money. At least not to argue. Used plastic bottles, plastic bags were scattered everywhere. It seems nobody cares. An ambience of the station must upgrade, facilities should also update as station is not only visited by locals but also  by foreigners as well. Food stalls should be audited for food safety plus security. For your reference. Thank you for everyone who helped.
Built in 1908 this is a typical colonial style station that needs some love a care to maintain as it has such long history.
Dead easy to get your tickets and travel. Found our way to Galle en route to Unawatuna. £1 each and a great experience. Don’t get a taxi take the train!,

ware of men saying they don’t want your money and showing you the way and then suddenly your in a Tuk Tuk and they want you to pay. It’s a SCAM. Don’t stand here with a map open. Not everyone in Colombo is a crook! The fort is over the river from the Station. Turn left as you leave.

Colombo Fort is not a world class Station by any stretch of the imagination, but it's nowhere near the worst either. I had pre booked tickets (prior to leaving Australia) and went to Colombo Fort the day before travelling to collect the tickets. The Station is quite easy to navigate, and they even have an office for Tourist Info.

When we compare huh to other Transport systems Train in one of comfortable transport worldwide if I'm not wrong, n luckily we have that n we don't maintain well,  on 10th of December 2019 (6:15am) i traveled Kandy to Colombo by Blue Line Train, and train was very Comfortable (Royal Saloon) but few points shortly need to mention which can correct if the concern authority's looking for it, The staff was sitting in passenger seats and kept the foot on the wall n enjoying, and when I look at the bathroom it was not in good condition which we pay 1075 rupees per person (I could write a lots of miner points but I stop with this) but we can do much more to expose our tourism n better service.
Be careful pickpockets operating through the station.  We got robbed. There is a possibility that officials are helping with it. Crowds do not help with the situation.
my trip was wonderful so I like it, also will make it again because of elephants in Nora lay town,musume

They seemed recently renewed the luggage storage. There are no wooden lockers anymore but are morgue-like steel lockers with keys. They said they close at 7:30 pm. Also, be aware of the scam. A deaf guy kindly helps you at the station and demand tips of more than 1000Rs when you have a seat on a train. テロの影響でサービスを停止していたらしい、ロッカーは復活していました。遺体安置所みたいな鉄製のロッカーで、鍵は備え付けです。聾唖者のガイドに要注意。車両に乗り込んできて寄付金を募ってきます（しかも相場が1000Rs）。まあ大した金額では無いし、駅の作りや乗り方も初見ではわかりにくいので、聞き倒すのもありかもしれません。

This is the main and biggest railway station in Sri Lanka from where you can get trains to every part of the country. Unfortunately, it is always too crowded and not at all organized or regulated. For starters, you will have to enter in a room to get tickets for Ella/Nuwara Eliya and that small room is full of chaos. It's full of people pushing each other with no one to tell you what queue to join. People can be often seen cutting queues here and there is no official to keep track of it. When you go inside the station you will see it's too crowded. There is a small snack shop which charges more than the MRP. At least at the railway station I would have expected some kind of regulation (which is missing in the rest of Sri Lanka anyway). A 1.5 L water bottle was being sold for 80 LKR when the MRP mentioned was 70 LKR. I raised this with the man at the counter to which he gave some crazy explanation. Since you cannot go out of the station once you have entered (they take your ticket back on your way out), you don't have a choice but to buy water or other essentials from here if you forgot to buy them outside. There is a bridge to access different platforms on the station. However, the locals rarely follow the bridge. Most people go from above the train tracks even though it has been clearly mentioned not to do so. There is a very small waiting room which is almost always crowded. It's better to sit on the benches than in the waiting room. Try to book tickets in advance and come to the station only 15 minutes prior to the departure of your train.

Just to let you know that if you go south even if you ticket says the train departs from Maradhana, you don't have to go this place. Colombo fort is the second stop so if you take the train at Maradhana Station you'll end up back at Fort in 5/10 mins. Normally is platform 6, blue and white train, be aware that if you buy 3rd class you'll be crammed inside or even hanging outside the door. For first class tickets is another wagon. Be ready.

There is lots of talk on this thread about scamming tuk tuk drivers. If you are at all concerned about this you can use Uber, for a tuk tuk or a car. Myself and my partner have been using Uber a lot in Colombo and Galle and though the local tuk tuk drivers don’t like it you can get a much better idea of prices for journeys. Sure you are probably paying more than local price but in reality this might amount to $1. It’s even possible to use Uber Intercity, though tolls are extra on top of the quoted Uber price. Most of the drivers we’ve had a young and courteous and a trying very hard to please.

By far the best and cheapest way to get from Colombo to Kandy. If you splash out on a first class ticket it's comfortable too and you get fantastic views from the observation carriage. There are A/C buses but the roads can be very busy and the journey time can take anywhere from 4-6 hours depending on time of travel and traffic levels. You can also take a private car of course but you're faced with the same traffic/time issues and the cost is likely to be around 8,000 Rs. I highly recommend the train.

This is the main railway station of sri lanka and connects you with ella and galle. Come early to get tickets, well organised

Fort Railway Station is a major rail hub and the main rail gateway to central Colombo (here most intercity trains running over the country end) For the information, Fort Station is a couple kilometres away from Maradana Station, the other major rail station in Colombo. USEFUL & PRO TIP Not many people knows that in Colombo there are also metered tuk-tuks, which are the fairest way to move around the city. Therefore, make yourself sure to get on one of these if you want to avoid to be ripped off.

Had a cold beer here most nights while in Tangalle. Nice and cold and cheap. First night I had the fresh fish. which was Barracuda, and mine was great. My partner had the Deviled Squid which she wasn't keen on. We had them give us a special Sri Lankan chicken curry the next night, which to be honest, wasn't that good. Lovely people and certainly worth a beer and a feed.

This was my first attraction I visited when I alighted from the public bus that fetched me from the airport. The architectural design of the station reminded me of the old Tanjong Pagar Railway Station in Singapore. This southern last station of the Malayan Railway line was also built by the British Straits Settlement government and facilitated travel to Peninsular Malaysia. It is now replaced by a faster modern Mass Rapid Transit System that better serves the transportation needs of Singaporeans. I took the train to Kandy from this station. I came on the same day and bought the second class ticket at counter 4 for 240 rupees. I see no reason to pay a higher cost to reserve the tickets which can be done at Counter 17. There are at least 2 to 3 morning trains to Kandy on the same day. When I came about half an hour before the first train arrived, there was no queue at the ticket counters. The Kandy tickets for 3rd class and 1st and 2nd class are purchased over Counter 3 and 4. All the counter staff at this station were very helpful. I asked one of them the direction to Slave Island and he showed me the direction. I asked about the process in purchasing the Kandy ticket and the explanation was detailed and clear. The ticket staff also informed the platform where I should wait for my train. I felt their service is spectacular and commendable. However, just a word of caution when buying ticket over the counter. It did not happen in this train station. It happened at Kandy Station. One of my friends bought his 2nd class ticket over the counter. It cost 300 rupees. He gave the counter staff a 1000 rupee note. He did not count the change on the spot and later found that he was short changed 500 rupees. I personally was also a victim for such similar scam when I bought a yogurt product at a provision shop in Ella and at a supermarket at the airport. I was alert and confronted the staff and he apologetically blamed himself for the counting error. I knew the intention was deliberate and tourists who are in a hurry became victims. It is also advisable to use smaller notes for such transactions over the counter. There is a canteen in the train station but I had breakfast before I came. There are also foreigners' toilets which I supposed to be cleaner than the local ones. The wooden benches at the platform had stains left by the birds and are not very clean. There are also signboards warning tourists not to leave their luggage unattended which I think is helpful to tourists. While the train station is old, the number of passengers plying the train to and from Colombo remains extremely high and it is the jumping board station for most tourists traveling to the inner regions of Sri Lanka. It is a cheap mode of transport for both the locals and foreigners. It is an eye-opening experience taking the train in Sri Lanka and in one way or another you will visit this old colonial station.

It is what it is - a busy, 3rd World railway station. We found it easy enough to purchase tickets and platform numbers were displayed. Tickets are very cheap. Make sure the attendant knows whether you want a return or one way. People will barge in front of you to get on, so just do the same. You'll possibly stand for much of the journey.

We visited this beautiful old railway station to get a train to Galle.It as a old colonial style architecture.The station has numerous platforms all are very busy with locals trying to catch the trains. The trains themselves are again very old with diesel driven engines that look ancient and bellow out black smoke. When the train enters the station the fun begins with locals jostling for position and jumping on the trains before people are getting off. Its a free for all. Once the trains are moving the doors of the trains are open and all the locals are hanging out the side of the train, it's a great photo.  A word of warning the tuk tuk/taxi drivers are watching people disembark the train from the bridges and as soon as you start walking to exit they pester you .

I was at the rail station to catch up the train to Ella. It was a very busy rail station and the information centre for tourist was very helpful. The rail station was in average condition, cleanness, and waiting room. Toilets weren't regularly cleaned. But the staff and the other people were really nice, always smile and friendly. This station belongs to the colonial period i guess. If you want to touch the local life and feelings you should go there bit early, sit back aside and look around.

Really busy environment. Staff generally unhelpful. Trains dirty and noisy - what more can I say? There are foreigners toilets - which you can get a key for - the locals facilities are shocking...Take care which train you get on - staff will put you on the wrong train...I think its a game they play!

Worth a look even if your not going on a train. Bustling busy station with tuk tuk drivers vying for your business. Really interesting looking at all the boards showing cost of trains to destinations all over Sri Lanka. All Places we had been to and how little it costs to get there. Loads of small eating places outside to get food, and after reading other reviews it’s worth getting food and drinks before you go on a train!! We had a chicken Biryani and it was cheap and delicious.

We got an Uber from Negombo to Colombo fort station in the rush hour which took  1 hour and 20 minutes. We arrived at 9am and there was no queue for second class ticket at no. 3 counter. The ticket inspector told us which platform to go to. When the train arrived we knew 2nd class was at the front but the train didn’t come right to end of platform, so we had to walk further up to get in. On previous trip advisor advice we took the first seats we found and had a good journey. A few people who arrived later had to stand so the train was full but not overcrowded
This is a very traditional but very busy railway station which is in need of an upgrade and  a huge clean up.  There was only one booth selling snacks and drinks.

This station was staffed by friendly helpful people but was very chaotic and confusing, The toilets were the worst I that I saw during my 5 weeks in Sri Lanka, they do have tourist toilets but they were locked and they could not find the key holder! A couple of booths selling snacks and drinks but nothing else, so grab drinks and snacks or fruit from the shops outside the station.

Main railway hub of the country and terminus for all intercity trains. A similar architectural design to Manchester Victoria station in England. Well preserve old colonial look has grabbed attention of many photographers. However, food and sanitary facilities here are not the best. If you're strict hygiene concerned, better avoiding. But, trip to Sri Lanka is not completed if didn't catch a train from here to central highlands,specially Kandy, Nuwaraeliya and Ella. These are the most scenic routes one should never missed. Or you can opt for southern coastal route as well.

It is quite an experience to take the train in Sri Lanka. This train station is much bigger than the one in Nuwara Eliya, you can see the lotus tower from the platforms, quite busy as well, there are trains going to almost anywhere. The coast line is pretty, also a little sad to see those roughly built houses... we stopped at a station that’s about 1 h away from Colombo, the ride going there was nice, train was not crowded at all, a lot of empty seats, but the ride back to Colombo was packed, so if you want to do that be prepared. The station looks really old, some trains are rusty from inside out, but they are still running, and look beautiful in a photo. I believe time has filled this place with stories, go and feel it yourself.

In the station, a public space and next to a small police station, there is a place, called Railway Tourist Information Service, where they don't give information and they just sell tours. Unfortunately, we believed the owner, called Sampath, and it was all a scam. They kept all our money, and they closed the place the day we have arranged a meeting in order to get our money back. He didn´t answer the phone or the emails, and the police next to this place did nothing. We wanted to make a legal denounce so we went to the police station, and they just starting saying it was our fault because we believe in that guy. PLEASE STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE!

Intrepid group arrived early to purchase tickets from railway station. Well worth a ride great views of the coast. It's a passenger train for locals to work in Colombo. Hints: no bookings reserved seating. Be early to pick up your ticket. Pick first seat available as train carriages fill up quickly. Even on public holidays.

We were a little concerned about how getting tickets to Jaffna would go after reading previous reviews. We were aware that we needed the ticket office near platform 17 and when you get to the main frontage of the station ( by the pedestrian bridge over the road) it is clearly signed. I would recommend getting the tickets the day before ( especially for Jaffna as it leaves the station at 5.45am). This takes the stress out of journey. Be focussed on not letting people direct you in different places, it really is clear. When you go in the ticket room the Jaffna desk is right over to the right. I think Kandy etc are more to the left and they had big queues. Oddly hardly any western tourists when we went. Next day we were off early and felt absolutely safe.  We were confused where to go when we arrived as there were a large number of people commuting that frankly just get in the way of trying to get in the station...another reason why you really should get your tickets the day before. A man checked our tickets and directly pointed out where we should stand for our carriage. Far less hassle than we thought. Be prepared for the first class being a relative term!

I used this station to travel to Galle. I avoided the rush hour and chose the 10.30 a.m train. It wasn't packed. I had the opportunity to sit on the right side and enjoyed the stunning scenes as we charged towards Galle. The train was literally huffing and puffing towards Galle. It cost only 240 LKR. Unbelievable value for money. It is safe and full of friendly tourists and locals.

Reading reviews here, it is easy to see that some people have experienced various scams. The place is chaotic and it is not clear which queue you should be standing in. My wife and I stood at different windows, in order to get our tickets. She found out that she had been sent  to the wrong one and so signalled me to stay put. We finally got our tickets and enjoyed an exciting train ride to Polonnaruwa. Taking the train is a great way to experience the country, but can be uncomfortable and stressful. This stage of our journey was fine.

Like many travellers on here a word of warning to be careful of who approaches you at rail, and bus, stations. It is very difficult to tell who is genuinely trying to be helpful and who is trying to sell you a ridiculously overpriced tour, ticket or tuk tuk ride.

Hub for all long distance trains.  Was very busy, asked at tourist information about the train we wanted and were told it was full and to get a later train.  We asked the ticket seller, got tickets, got on, got seats and had a very nice trip to Rambukana.  Don't believe tourist information.

Picked up pre-booked tickets without any problem. Showed our tickets to the man guarding the entrance and he advised us which platform to stand on and where to stand for our carriage. Only downside was we arrived for an early train and couldn’t find anything appropriate to eat at the station or on the train so recommend you take some yourself.

All long distance trains which include trains down South , up North to Jaffna and to the Central Hills start here. Train travel is the cheapest.  Very good value for money even if you book 1st class with AC. 2nd class (without AC) is equally comfortable if you are travelling to the cool climate of the hills. It's best to book online before travelling as trains tend to get crowded. ...3rd class travellers often have to stand. It's a great place to people watch as busy commuters come into the city to work and families with kids go on trips in the school holidays. ...

We went to the “Railway Tourist  Information Service” and they lied to us regarding how many km they would be driving us. To go from Anuradhapura and on to Sigiriya, Kandy, Nuwara Eliya, Ella, and then Mirissa we were charged for 1,200 km when the actual distance was 800km. We dealt with a man named Ajith. There are many reviews on Trip Advisor and google (general search) saying this place overcharges and cheats tourists. Don’t go here, look elsewhere. Further, there are many drivers who have a presence on trip advisor and have great reviews, just search for them. I would avoid using all services here. This service survives on scamming tourists.

We planned to take the train to Galle the next day, so we went to the train station the day before to buy tickets. The counter guy said twe can only buy tickets on the day itself. he advised us to come 30min-1hr before departing time. We came the following day at 8.30am for the train at 10am. Ticket price to Galle has now been revised to LKR240/pax instead of 180. We were hungry but didn't see any decent food, I bought some biscuits from the uncle cart. If can, avoid going to the toilet here, it's bloody disgusting. It's so aweful I can't even describe it. YEK x10000000000! When the train arrives, everyone starts rushing in like a very hungry mongrel who just saw a piece of meat. If you are slow you are left to stand, we had to stand :/ We were standing at the hallway, it was HOT and cramp; vendors kept walking up and down selling their food/bread/drinks. Not once, twice but soooo many times, it's already so cramp that you barely have space to stand and they kept passing by so many times and you have to give space when there are none. At one point I had to stick my face to the wall to make way for them. We had 2 big luggages with us, we had to also keep moving them around. Finally when a few passengers left, we stack up the luggages lying down on the floor on top of each other and sat on it. And finally when the 2 guys who were sitting on the steps on the stairs left, I quickly took a seat. It was interesting (not as cooling as I hoped). I could never have done this back in Malaysia. Finally we arrived in Galle, we took a Tuk Tuk to our hotel in the fort. I swear tuk tuks' exist to suck you dry, they charged LKR300 for 5mins ride.

Colombo Fort Railway Station is the main Railway head in Colombo. The station building is a colonial era building, which appears to have stuck in the 1980s. For this reason, it has an old world charm to it. It is a relatively small station, however, since Sri Lanka does not have a vast or elaborate rail network, the stations serves the purpose quite well. It is a busy station and appeared crowded. Station itself is maintained neat and clean. The railway staff at the station is quite helpful towards the tourist.

Don’t even bother. We got dropped off by the tuk tuk at the back of the station and directed around the front to the ticket counters. In our daze and confusion we were beckoned into the tourist information centre and relaxed thinking we were about to receive some help and direction. However, what we got was some guy making what I have come to believe is a bogus phone call to check on train tickets for us to Anuradapura. He then proceeded to offer us a package deal including driver and accommodation for £70 a day!!! He showed receipts from other travellers before us and everything. We were hesitant so were encouraged to check trip advisor because he has nothing but excellent reviews. Jokes on him, scam scam scam. We declined and we are so glad we did. We got seated tickets on our desired train and, despite him telling us the Kandy-Ella train was fully booked, we got standing tickets on the day. Avoid the tourist information guy, the train station itself is fine. Exactly what you would expect from a busy Sri Lankan city.

Ignore ALL advice that trains are fully booked in advance. Go to the counter which states "All Tickets" and buy a ticket on the day for the journey you want. They are unlikely to be full, but could be busy (Colombo to Habarana isn't). Second class is fine. Check in seat61.com for more on timings. The Tourist Office next door was misleading (and pretty dishonest). AVOID IT!

Its one of oldest railway stations in the world..ita having nice art work on the some of thw walls of thw station and even though its old there are many facilities available on it from last 7years ...and there are many restaurants and coffee shop on it..its having clean and good atmosphere...ita very well maintained by government there..

where time stands still ... many old fashioned low tech antique operation.. but efficient and used by nearly 500,000 people everyday.. its an place one would fall in love with if you are in to it... felt like i had visited the Hogsmeade Station in a harry potter movie... i urge everyone to take the train ride from this station to Ella.. you will feel like you are on the Hogwarts express

We had pre-booked tickets for the train to Kandy via an agency and had to pick them up before the train left and since it was a 7 am train, we took no chances and went the day before. EVER so easy. Just showed the confirmation details and my passport and the guy handed over the tickets for this and another trip later in our holiday.  We double checked the platform - number 2 - and came back the next morning. Staff were all very helpful and I was happy we didn't need to drag our bags over the bridge. Some other reviewers have said it's a dirty and chaotic place. Perhaps it's all about perspective. I've been using trains in India for over 20 years and by comparison, Fort station is paradise. We even had time for coffees and samosas from the canteen - which was a good decision as there's no food on the trains. Actually the station was the best part of the journey. Note to self: "Stop forgetting that you really do hate trains". Going backwards for two and a half hours in the freezing cold (thought there was supposed to be no AC in the Observation car) being jiggled about was torture.

My husband and I thought we would try something different and take a train from Colombo to Kandy for an overnight stay. We read all the do's and don'ts of riding on the train and thought we were well prepared. WRONG!!! No amount of preparation could ever prepare a person for the sheer madness and chaos of this place! We arrived a good hour before boarding time and tried to get 1st class tickets but they were sold out. No big deal so we got 2nd class. Stood waiting for the train and the moment those doors opened it was nothing but pushing & shoving with people trying to get on to grab a seat. I lost my husband in all the chaos but found him and thankfully he secured 2 seats for us...or so I thought! A guy who I guess was in charge of crowd control & placement stood in front of my seat not letting me sit down next to my husband and kept pointing to the next car. Then a young 20ish yr old girl boards and he puts her in my seat! My husband & I argued that no she wasn't sitting there but he completely ignored us. He then called to security and the security told the girl to stay!!!! Not too sure, but we suspect she might have bribed them to give her a seat. My husband was so upset as was the gentleman behind us who witnessed the entire thing,both began telling the girl off but no way would she move. My husband told me to come and sit by the window and he sat in the middle between the girl and I on 2 seats. It was a very long and uncomfortable & crowded ride. Too many people crammed into a very small space. I don't know how an elderly person or someone with a physical disability could travel this way and if they do then bless them!!

He will ask you for money later and will act all nice. After paying him a thousand we googled it and our good feeling was gone, well he played his scam out very well tho we haven't been scammed in a very long time :D.
Colombo Fort is the main railways station located at the heart of the city. Visited here to catch a train to Unawatuna. Staff were helpful. We reached early morning. The waiting room was ok.

The station as such is of old colonial style and it has not been remodeled. There are not many platforms and the ticket counters are also few. The entrance is impressive colonial style. Next to the station are a lot of shopping, but don't expect genuine stuff and also the locals don't seem very interested in selling their goods. because they don't expect you to bargain, even though the stuff is fake. The station is very dirty and not at all maintained well. The less said of the trains and the compartments.

This is the main train station in srilanka. but it is horrible place to see. very unclean and no facilities for foreigners also for locals. staff are very lazy and they don't inform very well. very disappointed place to have a tickets to go badulla.

My advices: Don't expect any information about train on it. You must only ask the people. So come erlier. Don't use offered service that tuk-tuk guys with buing Ticket on train. They said me, they buy me it cheaper for observation 1st class car becouse forainers have higher price. I used it, but they bought ticket for 2nd class for regular price not for 1st class!
