We took Podi Manike (leaving Fort at 5.55am) to Diyathalawa with a group of 16 including 8 teenage kids. The train travel and the scenery was breathtaking and the overall experience was excellent. We took the first class and the train was pretty much on time. Negative was the toilets which were smelly and not very clean. Most annoying thing was the hassle we had to go through to secure 16 tickets. If there is such a heavy demand wonder why the CGR does not put more trains on this sector as they could easily fill many 1st and 2nd class compartments without much trouble.

The Observation salon (non A/C) was very classy and the view was amazing for people sitting right at the end of the train. Second class seats were comfortable and had a less stuffed atmosphere, and although it's less cleaner than the Obs salon, it's definitely worth its cheaper price. (price gap over Rs.500) Vendors come to the observations salon as well with fruits/water. Seats are reclinable, but some are broken down a bit. CONS- Although the best view is at the rear end, towards noon it gets very sunny and the window glass is fixed shut in that row. The seats at the other end of the compartment are cooler, but the odour from the washrooms are strong, especially when the compartment door is kept open. There was a 2 hour train delay in our train; keep in mind when making plans.

We want to book tickets to Kandy but the tuktuk dropped us in front on the tourist information center (not official one btw) and a man guided us to the center. They offer expensive tours that can actually be done by half of the offered price in better hotels not even guest houses. They can be convincing as they relay on many tourist travel unprepared. So be aware of these kind of actions since you will face them in almost every city in Sri Lanka.

We used the old red train and booked in the observation coach. It was absolutely fantastic. A truly wonderful experience. We booked through agents so the tickets were quite pricey. Unfortunately it is impossible to book directly online. You have to go to the station to buy tickets. The journey took 10 hours and we loved the entire trip. Take along food and water. There is no restaurant on the train. Toilets were reasonably clean. Avoid the blue trains if you want an authentic Sri Lankan experience. We left 10 minutes late and arrived an hour late. The officials at Colombo train station were helpful and spoke good English.

Went to Colombo for a price giving function it was late when we arrived there so I planned to change my dress In waiting room The room is nice but the washroom is very bad so I didn’t used that and some place there is untidy
A great station to enter or leave Colombo. Information regarding trains in three languages on an electronic billboard. Several kiosks there low cost tickets can be bought
This is a public place and always busy station. Please note this is the starting station for any destination.

I had read reviews before going to the train station and they seemed very mixed of good and bad experiences. We got to the train station with about 40 mins to spare for our train at 10.30 from Colombo to Galle. It was easy to get a ticket and cost us each 180 for second class tickets. The guy at the platform told us which platform to go to as our train hadn’t even appeared on the board. Once on the train it was very busy and we ended up standing for the first hour but luckily people got off at different stations and we got a seat eventually. The train ride is about 2 and a bit hours, it’s not that comfortable and the toilet is basically a hole that goes straight on the tracks which we found to be an experience in its self 😂. Once at Galle, it is good to look when the trains are back the next day. It’s not a trip you can do in a day as the last train back seems to be around 3/4pm. Many people try to help you saying they work at the station but usually they do help but then have another agenda e.g. then try get you to take a taxi with them. On our way back to Colombo we ended up getting the bus back as we would have had to wait 2 hours for the train and we both we’re not looking forward to the journey again. Some men tried to get us to get in a taxi for 5000 which seemed cheap but in comparison to the train ticket it is not. In the end we just went to the bus station to ask and found a bus straight away the price was 340 each to get to Colombo which we took as we were confirmed seats, air con and was definitely a more comfort drive. We asked if we could get dropped off earlier then Colombo as we would have driven past our accommodation and it was fine to do that. It may take an hour longer to get to each destination but definitely more comfortable and I would recommend looking at getting the bus both ways.
It was not very clean the infrastructure was shabby, the announcements are not clear. no clear signages to understand about the train movements. if you are a tourist you need to try your luck.

This is where most trains pass through and most long distance start from , there are a few enquirers counters , in day time there is a small office where travellers can get help Book in advance for cross country trains in the reservation room , local train counters etc are all in English a large LCD screen shows times platforms destinations now Keep your bags with you at all times it’s busy busy place , avoid rush hours where many thousands commuters come in and out of the city Watch out for tuk tuk drivers outside , if you need transport onwards insist on a meter cab / 3 wheeler Enjoy it’s an experience

Read all reviews and take note. We got ushered into tourist office and told that in order to get tickets for following day we could only book them at the tourist Info office (NOT TRUE).. we then were offered an expensive trip with private driver. All seemed very legit and we actually considered it! We listened and took advice on places to visit but when we said no to driver and told him we were students he quickly got rid of us. We also got scammed by the ‘deaf’ man.. as we watched him sign to a young women and her son and thought he must be legit. So confusing and really sad as we thought the people in Sri Lanka were so lovely but this tainted it slightly. Keep your wits about you and try and not look lost as they clearly can see this a mile off.
Very busy place in center of colombo ..morning & evening office time are very busy ..price very cheap

We booked 2nd Class reserved seats from Colombo Fort Station to Kandi by making a phone call to the Fort Railway Station. We were quoted the correct price, given a receipt number and informed that we could pick the tickets up on arrival at the railway station. We travelled by taxi from our accommodation in Negombo, heavily laden with backpacks and additional day packs, and arrived leaving an hour before the scheduled 8.30 departure time on Good Friday March 30, 2018. After locating the appropriate ticket counter (Counter 17), we were told that there were no tickets booked for us, the receipt number was incorrect and there were no available seats on that train or any train to Kandy on that or subsequent days. As there was a line of other customers behind us, we left the counter and went to the Railway Tourist Information Office next door. The office was not yet open but a helpful person told us that we could put our bags down inside and wait for someone to help us. We accepted the offer, respite from a crowded footpath and a seat in an air conditioned office. After making his morning offerings, a man named Sampath told us that he would inquire about the availability of tickets for us. He came back some time later with the information that there were no vacancies on the 8.30 train as it was a very busy holiday, but he would see if he could get us tickets on a later train. He made one or more phone calls and told us that it would be possible to get tickets for reserved seats on the 10.30 train. After much coming and going we he returned and revealed that the seats were available only as part of a package holiday involving accommodation and drivers/guides. As we had already booked accommodation in Kandy, he "helpfully" put together an itinerary based on our travel plans. We were a little surprised at the quoted costs but, as new arrivals in the country and feeling trapped in Colombo on one of the busiest travel days of the year, were in a good position to be exploited. We agreed to a much shortened and cheaper version of the 15 day package that was offered. The full package cost the equivalent of (Australian) $1 700 for 15 days. This exceeded our budget and did not match our desire to plan our travel as we discovered more about the country and what we wanted to do in it. The final deal was for 2 one way tickets to Kandy, 4 nights of accommodation in Sigiriya, and a driver/guide to drive us from Kandy to Sigiriya, to our destinations for the next 4 days and back to Kandy on the last day. While we waited for the process to play out and our tickets to be obtained we observed the same scam being used on a succession of European and Asian travellers by the other officials in the Information Office. The accommodation in Sigiriya was good but the driver, while seemingly friendly, offered very limited advice or details and at every opportunity tried to persuade us to go to costly tourist attractions and buy safari and village tours, which we declined. We have since discovered that the accommodation was owned by the "tourist information officer" and he has been using this as his main source of bookings for a long time. This scam is well known to many within the tourism sector in Sri Lanka and is not limited to Colombo Fort Station. The cost of both the accommodation and driver were inflated, so that the 76 000 rupee ($A 654) we paid was well in excess of what we would have paid by independently booking. Stick to information from the official government tourist offices which are located at the airport and in a number of cities throughout Sri Lanka. They do not receive commissions or kick backs, offer good advice to travellers, are very well informed and put together itineraries that match your interests and allow you to see everything possible in the budget and timelines available to you. They also book you excellent  drivers that (while not seemingly cheap) have great knowledge that they enthusiastically impart. We found the accommodation bookings they arranged for us to always exceed our expectations.

Hectic & busy you can’t help but get caught up in the buzz of this station. The staff are friendly & helpful & will direct you to where you need to go. You exit the station into more madness but turn left & there is a market area that is worth a look.

We travelled by train a lot in Sri Lanka. So we used this station several times. It looks like chaos, but once you get near the platforms, you can ask about platform numbers, times etc. Beware taxi and tuktuk/taxi touts when you leave the station. Walk at least 100m away before flagging down.

We were about to get our tickets to Galle and the tourist information office just wanted to sell their tours. They do offer. Great customer service but sometimes it’s better to do your own consultation before believing on what they say.

Colombo’s main train station is very easy to navigate and it is the gateway to a number of cities in the country. I took the train from here to Galle and the whole process was easy, painless and quick. There is a left luggage facility which is very cheap and convenient and some places to eat. Next to the station there is a big market if in need of t-shirts, clothes, adaptors, etc. The trains are a bit old but comfortable and well maintained. The ticket staff is so friendly and helpful!

Caught the train from Colombo to Kandy.   Great part of our adventure of touring Sri Lanka - albeit dirty, noisy and definitely no class system at all.... but a great way to travel as driving takes forever.  We pre-booked the 1st class observation carriage on-line at home - you get reserved seats which is a MUST if you are joining these hectic, hot and overcrowded trains, and you pick the tickets up at the station.  Comfy enough seats - good views along the way.  An experience not to miss.  And oh so cheap.   1st class less than a Fiver....

I was transiting through Colombo and had two days to kill (took transit free ETA). Upon recommendation from a local friend travelled to Kandy by early morning train. Took a tuk tuk to station and its very easy to navigate around. My friend purchased the ticket in advance for me, so didnt visit the booking office. The train was on time and there was moderate crowd on platform.

Please read the reviews! Tourists Information Centre is a scam! My friend and I booked first class tickets and only to realize the day of our trip that we got third class tickets but PAID for first class! Once we arrived in Hatton, our driver kept rushing us to go home yet we paid for him for 4 days. He didn't work on the first two days (just a drive to the hotel on day one and to and from Adam's Peak on day two). Day three he kept using his phone and then he ran out of the vehicle with his phone and hid behind a rock wall so we wouldn't see him on the phone...we don't speak the language so no need to hide. Both of us felt VERY unsafe with him so we decided not to go with him to Kandy...instead we booked a real first class train ticket. USP Lanka Tours and Travels was the receipt we got from the Colombo Fort Railway Station: Tourists Information Centre (left side of the building). Please book with hotels as they are cheaper and honest! That is what we have learned from out trip....This company is nothing but a scam! TCR is Third Class Reservation and AFC is A/C First Class Reservation. Look at your ticket immediately!

In the station there is a tourist office run buy a guy called Sampath. He promised us the best tour with 1st class tickets (for which we paid handsomely) but ripped us off as soon as our tour started. We paid a lot of money for a car with driver (but he tried to push us into a big minivan). But the worst is that we paid through our nose for 1st class tickets, but then our driver told us Sampath (the owner) forgot to buy them and he could only arrange 3rd class tickets without seats for us, and when we said that we wouldn't agree, he said we'll then you can just leave the car and driver and figure it out yourself. Horrible horrible man and service, please don't book with this guy!

Once we knew we wanted to ride the old train from Colombo-Kandy, we searched online for how to purchase tickets.  It's highly recommended to purchase them a month prior to your travel day, as the 1st and 2nd class seat tickets usually sell out quickly.  With the help of our Colombo hotel staff, our tickets were purchased for the exact train #, date and time I wanted.  It's important to research all that in advance so you have seats on the train you want, because there are not only many date/time options but also many different types of train options and also many seating options.  If you don't research this in advance and (ideally) purchase your tickets in advance, you may have a lot of stress trying to do this at the station - many locals have limited English-speaking abilities and they may not understand what you want.  So you may be on a train to somewhere other than where you want to go! Once at the station, with tickets in hand, we didn't know where to board the train for closest access to our seats.  With the help of a local many who was mute, we got on the correct train car (he later asked for a donation to his mute organization).  The trains arrive/depart pretty much on schedule, which is good, as long as you make it on board!
The infrastructure has seen better days but the service was generally good. Tannoy messages were not always as clear as they could have been

I like train stations and this one was fun to hang out in.  I enjoyed the people watching and the trains coming and going.  There is one small restaurant where you can get sandwiches, sweets and coffee.  The staff here is very helpful showing you where your train and most importantly, your particular car will be.  I enjoyed my time here!

Every time is there some chaos, every time they are here full trains and lost soul of tourists, bad place for quiet time, refreshment because hot, nerveous and full of wandering people. Informations for foreginers are oriented on best Class of train many times II.class, but it means propeller and higher price. If You need anything ask anybody and maybe You get help. It is some policemans and some watch mans, but they controll the entries and some system only. Forgot colonial times...

Taking the railway anywhere is Sri Lanka is a cheap convenient way to travel around.We went a day in advance to book our tickets from Colombo Fort to Galle but were told they had to be purchased on the day.Put out of your mind now the chances of getting a seat 2nd or 3rd class as it just wont happen.The locals get on the station before Colombo Fort and so when it arrives its packed.Buying your tickets isn't a complicated affair but count your change as they ripped me off charging me more than the ticket stated.The station is clean and seems to be well run.Plenty of people to help in the purchase of your tickets.Overall you have to go here to start your journey and it isn't as bad as I thought it would be.Just happened to be here on a Sunday when the locals were all travelling down to Galle and it was packed

This is not a review of the whole station, more a warning based on our experience of asking for information at the station tourist office. We asked about trains to Jaffna. One of the peopel there told us; 1. There is not train line to Jaffna. This is a lie. trains run al the way from Colombo to Jaffna and behind to the north coast 2. That Jaffna is currently 40 degrees and therefore too hot for us. Again this was a lie. We arrived in Jaffna five days later and it was about 30 degrees. 3. We would get dengue fever in Jaffna - we didn't This man then dismissed any further talk about Jaffna and started drawing up an itinerary which took us no further north than Anuradhapura (which apparently also does not have a train line) Fortunately we ignored everything this man said and had a very good time in Jaffna, having first visited Anuradhapura (by train). Being new to Sri Lanka we do not know why this man was so determined to prevent us from making this journey, but it is unfortunate that advice given at the railway office for tourist information is so badly misleading.

this is the main place in srilanka. you can get all transport here. and if you want to know the railway schedule you can srch in google. for a example ( colombo to kandy train schedule) then you can get the all train time with the price. more info any help contect me +94779992177. this place have free wifi but its doesn't work good.

i am grading this station good rather than poor because considering how busy it is, it operates fairly smoothly in the general context of travel in Sri Lanka. The present station was opened in the early 20th Century and is the major rail hub of the country. Very many commuter trains depart from here as well as the longer routes operated by Sri Lanka Railways. Generally one can find ones way around but be prepared for crowds, a degree of pushing, and taking care.

Trains are an easy way to get around Sri Lanka, especially to the tourist destinations in the mountains. The Station itself is super busy but dilapidated - but still looks like its old colonial self. The staff is fairly friendly and helpful. DO NOT UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES THINK ABOUT USING THE TOILETS!

Be careful of the scammers and thieves that operate in this station. Avoid the ‘DEAF GUY’ who approaches you to see your ticket, he will later ask for 1000r+ donations and show you a dodgy ID card and pictures of his deaf school. (ALL FAKE!). Don’t fall for it, no matter how polite he is. Nobody will stop you donating, not even the station staff will do or say anything. Early morning lost tourists are easy targets, stay vigilant!

An easy train experience compared to some other places in the region. Just be careful when trains arrive of course, as people can get very pushy coming off and on. Just wait back when the train arrives, it's not worth it to push and shove for a seat. There is always room to stand, and nobody will push or shove you if you are ok with sitting on the floor, or next to the door (best views).

The station was opened in around 1908 or 1910 by the British who established the rail network around Sri Lanka. It basically hasn't changed since that time. It is a good example of the architecture of the time. Good to visit if you are interested in trains. The signs tend to be in Singhalese and Tamil with English a poor third so be careful when buying tickets. The view from the bridge across the main road outside of the local markets is good.

This is the main train station to get on regional or local trains. Very few people talk English. The ticket counters are marked but once you get the ticket it is basically just finding some local person who can help figure out your train. No announcement in English and no boards in English. The station itself is very dark and most trains have no lights till they are ready to leave. We had to go there a couple of times and every time it was the same. Give enough buffer time the first time you get there as it can be a bit overwhelming. And be ready to carry your bags as they do not have ramps to drag the bags.
this is the only station that you could connect to any City in Sri Lanka, bit untidy but its much better than in Indian Railways
While exploring Colombo with our helpful guide we also got to see this famous railway station. Here you can watch daily life going on. Good example of the British colonial time and architecture.

If you are into people watching, Fort Railway Station is the place! Always busy, always teeming with travellers and an assortment of vendors, bearers, taxi drivers and con men, all hoping to make a dime from you and me. But if you happen to be one of the travellers yourself, the place can be a trying experience. Written information is erratic, and chances are that you wait in line for what seems ages only to find that you have been in the wrong queue.

This railway station is at the heart of the Sri Lankan rail network and is in desperate need of a spruce up. The station is very crowded. The ticket queues were long even mid afternoon. If you like trains as I do then a look is probably what you will want to do. Don’t bother if you do not like trains or do not plan to take a rail journey. Beware of the tuk tuk drivers around the station. No meter and can’t be trusted.

As a tourist if you choose to travel to your desired destination by train, you ll probably have to come to the Colombo Fort Railway station. But often its not easy for a foreign national given the lack of digital or printed signboards or service personnel. Obviously you can try your luck asking for help from locals on which train is where, or whether the train is the right one. But always preferable to re-confirm with 2-3 ppl before you board. Bring your own food and drinks. Even if you dont happen to be traveling and say you are a photographer, the Fort Railway is an excellent place to get some snaps, in fact one of the best in the city. The building itself is historical, and the everyday commuters, the busy train schedules,  provide excellent subjects.

We used the station to catch a train to Kandy. We were pretty lucky with timing, in that the drivers' strike resolved itself just the afternoon before we were due to depart. We arrived early in the morning to pick up our pre-booked tickets. Some observations of our experience: 1) There are hordes of tuk tuk drivers just outside the station. These guys are pushy, not to mention sometimes downright stupid (if I just arrived at a train station in a taxi, do you really think I now want a tuk tuk?). Others will tell you to be polite and say "no thank you". I say, bugger that: If you show any acknowledgement, these guys will continue harassing you. Avoid eye contact, don't look at them, and pretend they don't exist. 2) There is no signage in English within the station to tell you which platform to go to for which train. This is ridiculous considering how many tourists use the station. 3) When we went in, the station officers checked our tickets. A well-dressed short man immediately came over and started gesturing to us to show him our ticket; he then used gestures to show us where to stand, which direction the train would be coming from, etc. He seemed very nice, and this was a big relief given the complete lack of information we'd received. When we got on the train he put our bags on (doing the same for the other tourists). He then wandered through the carriage showing everyone photocopied information about a school for the deaf and a donations sheet (all with R1000 donations). He gestured to us to complete the sheet and make a donation. And yes... I fell for it. I'm a skeptical, cynical person with no problem telling people to **** off, but amidst the noise and confusion and general crapness of the station, I fell for the social pressure got scammed for R1000. Don't let this be you - if you come across the same guy, just say no! (Or give him R50 for the help if you really want to - I'm 99% sure he's not really deaf!!) If you don't know where to stand, ask someone in uniform (in our case the train to Kandy was on the platform nearest the entrance, with the train door to the first and second class reserved carriages being on the far right as you enter the station). So that all sucked. The station staff clearly don't care about tourists - the "deaf" scammer had come to us when we were still talking to the station staff, and they seemed to have no problem with him leading us away (despite this clearly being a regular scam). They are presumably in on his take. Wtf is the point of a nice polite tourist information service if you're going to let scammers into the station to harass tourists?
This is a historic place and daily use hundreds thousand of commuters. There are lots of facilities have to to be improved including rest rooms, waiting area, and toilets.
crowdy and uncomfortable feeling. queue system isn‘t working, service @ stuff is on low level, stuff isn‘t well trained in englisch language... u can feel lost after few minutes :-D
The only way to travel to out stations through trains. Beware of pickpocketers as they are almost everywhere.

Last month (October) we took a train from here at 8.30a.m. to Kandy.  Platform was so easy to locate & there was a gentleman who showed us where to wait & then when the train arrived, he showed us where to get on & find out seats.  Very easy experience compared to stations in India.

This particular location is very busy throughout day and night. The station does appear very crowded but no beggars, litters or pick picketers.  All look happy, smiling and singing some songs or humming....The King Coconut is full of morning commuters, travellers and general public. Variety of food snacks, imported goods, toys, perfumes, bags leather shoes belts are available at bargaining prices without war of words or compulsions
You can book tickets for main cities like Kandy, Badulla, Jaffna in booking coutnrers which is in corner. Make sure that you are trying to book tickets prior to 30 days.

Colombo Fort Station is in the centre of the city and was opened in 1917, it is chaotic and always busy with a constant flow of intercity and commuter trains arriving and departing. I arrived into the station from Kandy by Intercity and then easily purchased a ticket from the ticket booth for a commuter train journey to Katunayake south station. I liked the buzz of the station and enjoyed passing through it,

This is the best place where you can catch any train towards any part of the country. Usually a crowded place. As many people, local and foreign alike use this place,government should do more for this place. There are canteens that you can get a decent meal but the public toilets are a nightmare. Authorities should attend to that to make this place a more pleasant one for everyone.

I was sceptic about my intention to travel by train from Colombo to Kandy and how to purchase my ticket - at the end I am glad I managed I took a tuk tuk to the Colombo Fort Railway station and was taken to the sales office at the end of the building where the clerk spoke good English and I got my ticket for the next day for not quite SLR 300 (1,5€) in a 2nd class reserved seat the station itself is a left over from Colonial times and has an old world charm, a big board just as you enter through the main entrance shows you where you will find your train ...I was lucky not to have to change platform, might be difficult with suitcase if you can't find your way just ask...plenty of polite railway personel around I arrived 30 minutes before departure and it was easy, shortly before departure time the place was crowded and the journey itself was great...2 1/2 hrs ....scenic Sri Lankan views

Started train services in Sri Lanka by the British in 1864 to transport coffee from Kandy to Colombo to be shipped to European countries. At present Fort station has become one of the main transport hubs for public and freight transports. Trains to all directions start from Fort station and bookings can be done before hand from the station or online. Who ever is interested in British architecture and to see a bit of local culture could visit Fort station as it is situated in the hart of Colombo. If you are planning to see the countries scenic beauty you should start the journey from Fort Railway station. Some of the services available are waiting rooms, changing rooms (utility rooms), cafeterias, special arrangements for disabled persons, etc........

I live in Colombo and this is an place never developed. My advice to travelers, don’t take trishow when you travel in Colombo, unless they are willing to switch on the meter for you. If not install Uber or pick me to your phone and order one. Train times changes frequently, so keep your ear on the speaker who announce the time table, sometimes they may not tell in English too. always better to talk to some passenger (a decent man/women preferably) and keep him informed that you intends to catch-up the particular train. So they will help you. Don’t worry majority of Sri Lankan’s are very helpfull and does not expect something in return.

We were caught in a sudden thunderstorm while taking street photos around the Fort Railway Station and Pettah area.  Fortunately, we ventured into a cafe name "Bo Sevena Hotel" serendipitously.  It turned out to be one of the most wonderful experience of our trip in Colombo.  The two persons who were manning the cafe were absolutely friendly, authentic and warm.  Their tea and food were tasty too.  Please drop by this cafe if you happen to be around the railway station.

1 of the centres of Colombo. As a tourist train journeys is 1 of the best ways to travel around Sri Lanka. Trains from here go everywhere in Sri Lanka connected by train. I found biking a train here pretty easy and people here speak good English. If you arrive here ton of tuk-tuks and buses to bring you anywhere in Colombo.

Locals will tell you they think you can book online, but the reality is all train travel needs you to rock up st the station and buy the tickets in person. The office closes for lunch and it's pretty chaotic when it reopens at 1pm; the Sri Lankans pay little regard to queuing. Be prepared for long lines and some bewildered looks as you try navigate which window to buy from. Yes it looks easy, but in reality it's anything but. Elsewhere the station is busy and a bit run down, but what would you expect?

Fort Railway Station is the Transportation Hub of Sri Lanka built by English.You will end up here if you take a train in or out of Colombo. Transportation is plentiful outside the station, by either Taxi or TukTuk. Train travel is a very convenient and cheap way to travel through Sri Lanka.  You could travel to several destinations in luxury and at a low rate using the Expo Rail. You can find a train to Kandy, Negombo, Galle, Anuradhapura, Trincomale, Baticoloa and Jaffna from here. Luxury trains with AC also are available here to serve you. Take care about your valuables from the  thieves outside the station. I have used Colombo Fort Rail station very often and it has been fine. I live in Kandy and work in Colombo and I travel home and back by trains and I have to come here as the trains start the journeys from here. Finding the correct platform and train seat was very simple.Travelling by train is comfortable and enjoyable and fast as they are not held up due to traffic. In most occasions, Ihave used this station. They will announce about the journey of the train in Sihala, Tamil and in English languages.  I have gone on train to visit many places like Kandy, Badulla, Anuradhapura, Matara and Jaffna using the Sri Lankan railway service. it is low cost and a very efficient way to view the beauty of Sri Lanka. The station has many ticket counters and all are numbered, Above all, there is a list of places they stop and the cost involved for the journey to different destinations.  There are different Numbered ticket counters for different routes and they are nicely notified by signboards. If in doubt go to counters 6 or 7 which are the inquiry counters where you can get help or even ask the schedules. We traveled on the Sri Lankan trains to Hikkaduwa, Galle, Kandy and Negombo and had no problems at all finding the train times and getting the correct trains. 500 or 1000 LKR notes are best for the ticket counters as the train prices are very cheap in Sri Lanka.There is a digital board displaying the time schedules of the trains destination at a particular time. If you travel to "Nuwara Eliya" you get  absolutely beautiful scenery. Cost was 2200 Rupee's in the 1st.class with meals and drinks. Took approximately  6 hours and I loved every minute of it.You'll certainly enjoy the experience. Train travel whilst in Sri Lanka is a must. Much more pleasant than catching the buses but having continuity in ticket prices and bookings does not exist. First class gives you air conditioning and generally a seat (not too crowded) but best to only have carry-on luggage. Third class is with many people as possible. Once you have your ticket go through the entrance and there is a large screen which will tell you the platform number, it changes between Sri Lanka and English every 30 seconds or so. When on the correct platform you can ask a member of staff which end of the platform the carriages for 2nd or 3rd class will arrive. Once the train starts to appear pick you bags up and get ready for the rush to the door. People rush to get into the train which is  no different to ‘rush’ hour at any station in the world. Keep your ticket as you will need to hand it in when you get off the train. The trains are heavily used in Sri Lanka so if you are slow getting on you may not have a seat. If so, and you don’t mind standing, you can stand by the open carriage doors which is a great way to see the country side pass by. You can either use the  website or instead just go to the station to book the tickets. But better to inquire beforehand the time schedule of the train to your destination if it is a long distance one. Try to get an ‘express’ train rather than a ‘slow’ train as they are slow. If you have the time and like the countryside, you must take a trip on the railways from Colombo Fort, It is worth a peek inside, if you are not traveling, there are public restrooms as well. I recommend you to start your journey from Fort station in the train to your destinations.

Colombo Fort Station is the main rail gateway to central Colombo, it is the main station of the most intercity trains in the country. Fort Station is situated in the heart of the city, located next to the Colombo Fort and Pettah Market. This is very crowded place, therefore, no one should visit the station to see this station only to see, if not travelling by train. In my view, there is nothing special or interesting things in the station to observe.
We had to collect tickets from here so it was on our itinerary anyway..a large old building worth a look...food shops around too.

We ere travelling from Colombo towards Galle. The tourist Services office staff are very helpful and friendly for all train info. Train travel is slightly crazy but really cheap, good way of seeing the country. Try a short eat from the station restaurant on platform 1 - tasty! The toilets are the station are horrible - make sure you have a tissue in your pocket!

This is very crowded place all 365 days 24 hours. Yet the place is not refurbished as i have seen for over 30 years Could be hard to manage such a crowded place as this is the main railway station of the entire country. But should take measures. beggars is a nuisance too.

This is the main railway station in Sri Lanka. So needless to say that if you need to find a train to a specific destination, this is the best place. nothing fancy here but it works hehe. a lots of shops around the station from fruits to daily meals. be there a bit early so to avoid last minute panics and rushing.

If you wanna travel with trains in Sri Lanka and if you're in Colombo, this is where it all starts. Located on the opposite side of the central bus station, it pretty much stands out of the crowd and anyone would know this place. I actually used this station as a landmark to find my way for many time in Colombo. I traveled to Galle and came back from Kandy using this station. There are food court and standard bathrooms available here.
Old station but importantly serve it's purpose, daily commute for many & surprisingly punctual too albeit very crowded during rush hours... hanging outside the train!

The Colombo Fort Railway Station is the main point of departure for trains to all points of the country such as  Kandy, Nuwara Eliya and Jaffna. Lovely old building which needs TLC. We visited the wooden Tourist Enquiries area where we were given vague information in response to our specific questions. The man became a lot more animated and effective when a couple of 20 something young ladies turned up and it became clear he had put together a private tour for them. There is a government/private JV in relation to this office and we had much better service and replies to our questions at the General Enquiries counter (11) run by the Railway itself . There is a dedicated area (17) to book first class sleeper and observation cars which is split into separate counters for different routes. First class is cheap and the only way to travel by train..! The 3 wheelers immediately outside the station are largely rip off merchants so best to get one dropping people or walk to the main road and make sure you get one with a meter.
We took the train towards Anuradhapura from here. You can book 2nd class only there will be no airco

One would not go especially to see this station if one was not travelling.  We took the train to Anuradapura from the station and we were ‘befriended’ by someone who showed us where the observation car that we had booked was.  A tip was expected.  We also arrived back into the station from Galle and the platform was very crowded with people trying to get on. It is very conveniently located close to the centre of town.
There are several trains bound to countryside. So you can find your way through train which is very cheap compared to other form of transpotation.There is  counter to reserve ticket in advanced too.

Such a busy station, good to people watch!  Would recommend using the bathrooms if you don't desperately need to go.  If you need a tuk tuk beware of the drivers as you exit.  They will refuse to use meters and will overcharge.  Make sure you barter and do not accept their first price.  We asked away from many.  We were given 600-1000 rupees in price to our hotel, ended up paying 300.

I booked, online, a train ticket (and return) from this station to Colombo.  Seems like this is typical of most tourists, as the local "helpers" can spot many tourists and offer to help navigate.  I was glad to have a pre-booked ticket though, as it made getting a seat easier on the train.  The station is marked okay, and the announcements include an english one, however, typical of many stations, the loud speakers for announcements are lacking in clarity.  Still, the outbound train was easy to find and it was right on time.  There is a good online website called Seat 61, which was very helpful.  Also want to mention the train station personnel were very friendly and helpful.

We were planning to travel to hikkaduwa from the colombo fort railway station. The first problem was finding the right ticket counter out of the many. There is an information service counter where you can get help. They are friendly and accommodating. Standing for 2 hours in a crowded train didn't seem to make sense, so we got down. The ticket counter guy was nice enough to refund our train ticket fare. We took a bus instead which was much more comfortable and we got seats too. For a long distance i would suggest bus.

Colombo Fort Staion is right out of the history books .. There are a lot of ticket counters and finding the one you need can be quite hard( there is a tourist info office outside though)  there are steep steps to manage between platforms and it can be quite manic at times..

This station served the commuters who travel daily from their hometown to the city center every day during weekdays. In addition it also served tourist who travels down south from Colombo. It is a classic building with classic touch.
The Fort Station has a rustic and olden age feel, but the services and standard of the station and Sri Lankan trains need to Improve slot. Don't even think of using the washroom at this place.

I am not sure I would have gone to visit as a standalone attraction but as our train from Bentota terminated here so we had a look see - the station has a lot of history with some interesting architecture, if you are planning a train journey and traveling light come a bit early and have a look around - get a good spot for a coffee and enjoy the views.

The Colombo Fort Railway station harps back to the 1950's and is chaotic at best. The staff are very helpful but buying a ticket can be a taxing exercise! I have travelled to and from The Fort to Galle, Kandy, Bandarawela and Ella. Recommend that one travels outside of peak times to Galle as it is a commuter line and gets very crowded - 2nd Class or 1st Class is recommended. On the trip to Kandy and beyond I recommend booking in advance, if you can. As this is a popular tourist route, the trains are often very busy. 2nd Class is fun as the windows can be opened and passengers are often found sitting at the doorways filming the wonderful scenery. 1st class is airconditioned and the windows are kept shut. Recommend carrying a light sweater is travelling in this class as it can get cold.

You need to take a train to NANU OYA which is the station closest to the Hill Station of Nuwara Eliya.  The ride is the most scenic you will probably experience in this part of the world, with mountains, waterfalls, and lots and lots of greenery.  It really is a wonderful train ride, on a not so comfortable train, but if you can get tickets on the Tourist Scenic Car with it's relatively large windows, you will really, really enjoy it.  By the way, trains in Sri Lanka cost next to nothing!!!

This is a busy railway station, teeming with people and tuk tuks. The public toilets are, as one would expect, heavily used, and are not properly maintained. There are several options to purchase snack food. The ticketing process is messy and tiresome. The information as to where to purchase tickets leaves a lot to be desired. There is, however, a separate office where real people will provide you with rail travel advice.

Actually, there is no much to see if you are going to make a dedicated visit to Fort station. But it is worth having a walk around and take some photographs if you are travelling from  Fort. It is the rail hub in Sri Lanka in collaboration with Maradana railway station and Maligawatta train yard. This is one of most busy places in Colombo. The staff is really helpful. Train time tables are displayed in screens and announced time to time in Sinhala, English and Tamil languages. Furthermore, the train time tables come as a mobile phone app. You can do online reservations as well. There is an  information center dedicated to foreigners. Anyway the place crowed, dirty, not maintaining very well. Lavatories are old and not clean. No enough facilities in rest areas. Since this is a crowed place always  keep an eye on your valuable things. This building has been constructed similar to Manchester Victoria Station during British Colonial period and opened in 1917. It still owns its architectural elegance. But my opinion is,  Maradana station is architecturally more superior than this. They still use old  controll systems, machines and furniture. It will be a kind of different experience. This station has been used to shoot the film A COMMON MAN starring Ben Cross and Ben Kingsley.
Central point of Sri lankan railway; always busy and beware of strangers also take care your belongings

You have to go through a jungle of people and get pushed around alot. Not convinient as they do not have a proper online booking system which would make it MUCH easier to book tickets. Should be prepared and buy tickets early. The people there help you out and the people behind the counter have been very helpful. Very dirty station, could use a repaint and the restrooms need ALOT I mean ALOT more cleaning and painting and facilities for a station where 1000 of people travel everyday! Come on....
Easy to find and people are very helpful. But inside bit dirty. Although few displays are not showing the information number of display boards are there to find train time tables
all long far trains are starting from colombo,specially upcountry, north east and east,well schedule
I wouldnt recommend it, unless you havent seen any old trains. Its not ornamental nor does it have any unusal architectural features worth the visit. But i would recommend taking a train ride!

This building has been preserved since the British era. This place is crazily packed but it is the main train station that will take you to majority of the cities in Sri Lanka. This place is definitely not for the feint-heart and you have to display your travelling wits when travelling from this station. Be extra careful with your possessions.

keep your bags with you , smile and carry on . tickets can be purchased for all over sri lanka from here . ticket windows are numbered . lots of tuk tuk drivers and people around just keep your wits about you ....... good cheap food in stalls near by

The station is situated in the center of the city. There are multiply ticket counters so you need to ask around for exact counter where you need to buy the tickets. Please make sure you check the ticket dates and details as I asked for current date ticket and the representative gave me ticket 2 days later dated ticket
Starting with the ticket counter, they do not smile or talk plesantly with the traveler.Terible platform floor with uneven tiles. Place is litered with garbage. Maybe a few garbage bins will help.
Comparing the railway stations in South Asia, this can be marked as  average. Cafeteria and wash rooms are there. But not so good.

This is Sri Lanka's largest railway station, situated as it is, in the heart of the island's commercial district in Colombo. It was built during the colonial era of the mid 19th century, and reminds one of the Victoria Station in London. But the resemblance is fleeting. The station is dirty and drab, and desperately needs a facelift. A continuous maintenance crew is necessary to ensure the cleanliness and functioning of its facilities as it serves a constant stream of office workers and holiday makers throughout the year. No self respecting individual would dare use its waiting rooms or washrooms, the ticket collectors and other officials are indifferent or rude, and rarely does a train arrive or depart on time. Such a pity. So much potential. It is sad when an old building goes to rack and ruin.

We had the unfortunate luck of trying to catch a train during a medical student strike and could not reach the train station in time. So we tried the next best thing to get another train to Kandy but the counter staff are extremely rude and not helpful, The tourist information center doubles as a car rental. We finally was able to get to Kandy with a hired car as it was getting late and quite frankly was disgusted with the train service staff who was unapologetic or helpful with our predicament. Lesson learned, when relying on public transport always have back up plan in case of strikes or any other local political drama.
In Sri Lanka people mostly use trains because of low cost and fast transportation. But it has limited locations to travel by train. But if you will travel by train it will be great experience.
I have been to Kandy from fort station early morning. Station was nice and clean tough station needs renovation. Was able to get tickets day before for Kandy.

Reviewer Location: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC. Tripadvisor performs checks on reviews as part of our industry-leading trust & safety standards. Read ourtransparency reportto learn more.
Review Text: Except the colonial architecture , the place is very badly maintained. I guess this is a problem with Sri Lankan transportation system in general. They could have done a lot with this place as a tourist destination if it was properly maintained.

We booked tickets to Galle they day before (in itself a challenge) and when we showed up for the train, it was an event - we were travelling with luggage which is clearly unusual for a Sri Lankan train (unless you are travelling with caged chickens which is a check box on the their website) and it took time time to drag our cases through the gates and over rails. There was also a 'helpful' man that showed us how to get to the right platform with trying to lug our cases up over the stairs). In fairness we would not have found the over the tracks path without him but he then proceeded to hit us with the "i'm deaf' signs and asked for a 'donation'. Didn't cost much (we gave a couple of hundred rupee, when he was asking for a couple of thousand), but takes the edge of the helpfulness of it. The train was OK - we were in the first class observation carriage (although not the air-conditioned one a it wasn't running that day, so it was a warm 2.5 hours to Galle, with no food on the train and drop toilets). But we'd brought provisions so were OK. The trip was worth it, you travel by the ocean for most of the trip to Galle and go through many villages, so it was really interesting and only 800 rupee each. The Galle station is also massively busy, OK in the station but you will be absolutely harassed by tuk tuk drivers the minute you step foot outside. If you are staying in the Galle Fort area, it's easier to just walk out and go around the Galle Cricket Stadium and you'll find the couple of gates into the fort - it's under 850m to get into the fort area from the station. We tried to book tickets back from Galle to Colombo (for first class tickets you can only book in person and a day or so prior to the trip  - you can't book 2nd and 3rd class) but their system was down and advised that we try tomorrow (shrug) - they day we wanted to leave - or take a train to Matara to book there (an hour away). Ended up booking a taxi (which was horrific) but it's with taking a train trip.
Get to this railway station to head out of Colombo, the building housing the railway station is a must visit if you are inclined towards architecture and culture/history of a city.

We walked past here from Fort to Pettah one evening as hoards of people were going home from work.  It was an amazing experience to be part of this bustling scene.  We did not go into the station, but cold see a train and people getting on and off it from the road.  We would love to go on that train for a short distance, but not when it is so busy!

This is a historical station which does not appear to have been renovated since being built. My experience of it may be coloured by the fact I was using it over the New Year weekend and maybe counters that were closed would normally be open. I got more information from a dapper man who saw me looking lost and came up to volunteer information about the trains (although I really suspect he was looking for a tip or for me to decide to take his taxi instead) I wanted to take a trip to Mount Lavinia on the Galle line for the experience and, although I managed on the day that I travelled to buy a 2nd class ticket on the 8.35 train, no matter what counter I went to could anyone tell me the times of returning trains. It was only when I arrived in Mount Lavinia that I could establish there was a return train in 5 minutes or I needed to wait four hours. The actual train ride consisted of standing absolutely squashed and unseeing in the vestibule (but fun talking to fellow passengers, some of whom had suitcases and didn't comprehend they would be standing for 2 hours to Galle) . I might as well have bought a third class ticket - not that either was very expensive which explains why there is no spare money to do up the station. I ended up catching the third class only (15 rupees instead of 20) return train at 9.05 which had plenty of unoccupied seats and pleasant fellow passengers and I was back at Fort before 9.30

This station serves the entire Sri Lanka very well. But if yo are a Traveler who are going to use this, be ready. This is not a very clean and tidy place. This station is very crowded. Specially 6.30 a.m. to 6.30 p.m. How ever there are facilities to book long distance trains. So allays book your train. Most of the times trains goes as scheduled.
Its interesting to know about the public lifestyle of Sri Lankans. Most of the people come for work daily use the railway from very far from Colombo.

The Station is clean and connects to all parts of Sri Lanka where trains travel. Reservations can be made on Main lines at the reservations Counter ( Counter No 17). Better to decide prior to your journey and reserve your seats in advance at least 25 to 30 days ahead as Train Journeys are very popular and gets fully booked in no time.

We met there for a guided tour which was supposed to be street food. Unfortunately our agent here in Australia failed to understand that it was a public holiday for new year. So our guide took us to many spots which were open. This was a really great look around Colombo while it was really really quiet.

We recently travelled from Colombo to Galle by train with our 2 children aged 10 and 11. The tickets cost 180slr each for 2nd class or 100slr each for 3rd. The journey takes just over 2 hours. The train was busy but not crowed and we easily found seats all together. Its best to get window seats on the side of the ticket office as this will give you a brilliant view when heading down the coast. We bought some water and snacks before we left the station but you can buy small snack items on board including the shrimp fritters that are so popular in Colombo.

Counter 17 for reservations. Even if they tell you a train is fully booked, go there at 5 am when the office opens and, unless you are a he group - you will surely get a seat on the train to Ella. Tuk tsk drivers outside the station are among the most dishonest in Sri Lanka so be careful and perhaps get the metered ones.

If you are travelling from the Colombo to any city via train then probably the station you could catch the train is Colombo fort.there are 9 platform available and each have been numbered . Once you enter to the station on the 4 rd platform you could found the digital railway time table and it includes the train destaination ,departure time and the platform number which train arrived. When it comes to sanitary facilities ghee are number of toilets avaialable and the toilets in the first platform are clean compared to others.there are 2 rest rooms for ladies and gents separately. Also 2 canteens available in the 3 rd platform.
Very busy place and largest railway station in Sri Lanka with more than 10 platforms. Services are middle range.
Interesting relic of old times with far too many passengers.  Helpful staff.  Booking tickets can be difficult.

Special Service for tourists and others is being provided by Sri Lanka Railways by introducing a special coach to intercity and other express trains. This air-conditioned coach consists of very comfortable seats with television and wi-fi as services. Catering too has been included. This service has been launched with private sector participation. The Railway has been in existence in Sri lanka from.the days of British rule then known as Ceylon. The British built a sturdy and practical railway network mainly to transport the tea from the hill country to the city of Colombo and thereon for export .The British railway system later extended to the Southern Beaches and to the east and to the North. This was the most convenient and cheapest mode of transport in the days gone by, and Still .ferries thousands of long distance workers to and fro from their places of work on a daily basis. the more popular line for the holiday maker is the “Udarata Manike,” which simply translates as the “Maiden of the hills” which covers th entire picturesque mountain terrain and the popular tea country…. this has an observstion car which can be prebooked and if you do not want to make the entrie 8 hour trip an alternative route is the run from the Kandyan city of Kandy to the colder climes of Nanu Oya from where you will be able to get to the hub of Nuwera Eliya which the British called as “Little England”… Also another option is the convenient and comfortable Colombo/kandy/Colombo with airconditioned carriages that takes just two & half hours one way. The unique feature of travel in Sri Lanka is its reasonable distances between the hill stations, archaealogical sites and the calming southern beaches that attract thousands of tourists. In addition to being able to travel with the local population which still use the train on a regular basis. One can also now get to the lovely white sandy beaches and the charming mangroves of the East Coast, where surfing, and sailing have become very popular after years of taboo owing to the thirty year civil war. The Northern Railway system reaches the famed beaches of Trincomalee and Batticaloa and it is a worthwhile expedition. Railway Journey in Sri Lanka is “to see once is worth more than hearing 100 times” Day Excursion to Kandy 0615Hrs : Pick up from the Colombo hotel and transfer to Fort Railway station to board the train to Kandy. Customers advised to organize the pack breakfast from hotel, while on the journey, they can have the breakfast on the board. Arrival to Peradeniya station by 0900Hrs and you will be met by English speaking Chuffer guide with A/C Car or Micro van. From Perdeniya drive to Pinnawela Elephant orphanage to see the Elephant bathing and baby baby elephants. Drive to kandy, upon arrival at Kandy visit Temple of the tooth relic, City centre, arts & craft centre and local markets. Lunch at local restaurant by 1400Hrs. After lunch you will be taken to Kandy railway station to board the train at 1500Hrs to Colombo. You will arrive at 1745Hrs at Colombo fort railway station and transfer to your chosen Hotel in Colombo.(Tickets on first class or 02nd Class) Day Excursion to Galle 0615Hrs : Pick up from the Colombo hotel and transfer to Fort Railway station to board the train to Galle. Customers advised to organize the pack breakfast from hotel, while on the journey; they can have the breakfast on the board. 0655Hrs train leave from Colombo to Galle and arrive at 0950Hrs. On arrival to Galle railway station you will be met by English speaking Chuffer guide with A/C Car or Micro van. He will take you around the Galle city and Unawattuna beach for a swimming. Lunch at Local restaurant in the Galle fort area. Please refer the description of Galle: Galle -  Sri Lanka’s most historically interesting town is Galle. It was a major port until about 100 years, but today still handles shipping and sailing boats in the natural harbour. Stroll around the lighthouse and harbour or visit the old town where you can see the traditional lace makers and wood carvers and purchase some the finest souvenirs. The Dutch Fort – Galle - The South Coast’s major city is Galle, whose oldest landmark is the massive Portuguese and Dutch Fort which is a “World Heritage Site” in which the central city is contained. But the city may be much older. Some scholars believe it to be the “Tarshish” of the Old Testament, to which King Solomon sent his merchant vessels, and to which Jonah fled from the Lord. Today, the 90-acre Galle Fort shows no evidence of the Portuguese founders. The Dutch incorporated the Portuguese northern wall in a great rampart in 1663. A second, taller wall was built inside of it. Between the two walls, a covered passage connected the central bastion with the Fort’s two half bastion’s overlooking the sea. Around 1520Hrs, you will drop off at the Galle railway station to board the train to Colombo, which leaves at 1545Hrs and arrival in Colombo 1840Hrs. Upon arrival at Colombo you will be transfer to your chosen hotel in Colombo. (Tickets on 01st Class or 02nd class)

ambalangoda train station to columbo and back gain what an experience. When we arrived at the ticket office to purchase our tickets (around £2 each!) and saw the board saying all seats were fully booked, my heart sank. This is a must do experience in SL ad I was afraid I would not be able to show my husband and daughter why.  With some trepidation I accepted the last available tickets for Ella to Nanu Oya in 3rd class.  I have been to SL many times as it s my ancestoral home, although it was 22 years since my last visit; I knew 3rd class was probably going to be cramped, uncomfortable and the locals travelling could be accompanied by any manner of goods or animals and be packed into the carriage!  Despite being shown to the embarkation point off the end of the platform in the dust; I was very wrong. It allowed us to get an amazing picture of the train as it arrived. The allocated seats were covered in a lovely blue PVC and padded! There were no standing passengers and everyone was very civilised. The windows were large enough to lean out of but better still we were able to sit with our feet hanging out of the door for long periods (we felt we had to let other people have a go) and get the best views of the passing countryside up into the tea country..... just the best part of the holiday by far. A couple of traders came down the carriage with filled buns and fresh roasted spiced nuts for just a few pence. Simple pleasures are always the best. At some of the stations local farmers bring their vegetables to the train and trade is done on the run literally as the train is moving, just as it has done for decades. Just do it and don't be put off by people who tell you tales.  We thought the 2 1/2 hour journey would be tiresome.... next time we are doing the whole day trip, it was fantastic.

We were leaving for Bentota and bought our tickets in advance, not knowing how it worked. Basically, only 1st class will get you reserved seats, but you must do this in advance and through an agency - check on-line. It will cost you considerably more, but its still cheap. Otherwise, you buy a 2nd class ticket, and tickets to destinations 1-2 hours' distant are cheaper than a tube ride in London. Don't expect to get a seat, but relax - once you get on (it may seem daunting, but just move forward), settle in a place (by the doors are preferable for air and views, but between the seats is okay, too). Expect vendors and some beggars to walk around and over you - the cut pineapple and pomengranite seemed safe enough and delicious. Note: Upon returning to Colombo, passengers getting on the train will not wait for you to disembark first. Look to see where Sri Lankans are exiting and follow them. Although it can be stressful, it was a pleasure feeling the air through the open doorways. There's usually a local hanging out the door behind you, so not too much worry about falling out. It's also a great opportunity to meet other travellers.

At this point he started talking about booking a tour through him "we thought here we go" After a lengthy chat and giving us some figures "which sounded a very good deal" we decided to book and I'm glad we did. We would have never been able to see as much of Sri Lanka so easily without this tour. It was arranged for our driver to pick us up from our hotel in Kandy and that he did. This is when we met Lahiru Dissanayaka our driver and tour companion for 5 days. Lahiru was an absolute godsend and became a very good friend over them 5 days. We saw everything possible in the time we had and Lahiru's knowledge of the places we visited was exceptional. We saw everything we could from our Kandy City tour on our first day. Kandy to Nuwara Eliya on our second day. Nuwara Eliya to Matale, Dambulla and Sigiriya on our third. A jeep Safari at Polonnaruwa "we saw so many elephants, it was a beautiful sight" and all the ancient ruins on our fourth. On our fifth day Lahiru took us from Sigiriya to the drop off point of our choice which was a long trek to Trincomalee seeing and stopping at some beautiful sights on our way. It was sad to see Lahiru go and I would highly recommend Rail Tours to see all the beautiful sights of Sri Lanka at a very good price. Just take your time when your in the office and point out what you want to see and when and you won't be disappointed. A big thank you to Rail Tours and a bigger thank you to Lahiru Dissanayaka.
