One of the main down turns is the very discourteous staff from Ticket collectors to the booking office. They have forgotten that it is the "PASSENGER" whose fare pays them their salary. To them the passenger is a botheration. They glorify in the 8.30 to 4.30 job they do, like the man just mechanically issuing tickets, the person who announces train arrivals or departures merely stating a train is cancelled not bothering to inform what time the next train would be. It is a rudderless leaderless place  with a station master who prefers to remain invisible.

Built by the British, so fairly functional and durable, but in need of upkeep. Could also do with (clearer) English signs and announcements and more food/drink stalls at all times of the day and night. Very clean though, compared to a lot of other stations in South Asia. Surrounding region has street markets that are worth a visit.

It was built by the British and looked grand in a Sri Lankan way. Due to security reasons most of it has now been cordoned off and looks depressing. It needs to be renovated and brought to its old status!!
Main Rail Way Station in Sri Lanka,You can get any train from here. Just visit http://www.eservices.railway.gov.lk/schedule/homeAction.action?lang=en

Had a 20 min stopover on the way to Jaffna on Yaal Devi and return trip on the ICE. It would've been great if the traveler knows which platform the train comes to as it helps to identify which exit to inform the cars/transfer pick up's to arrive.

Fort Railway Station is a major rail hub in Colombo, Sri Lanka. The station is served by Sri Lanka Railways, with many inter-city and commuter trains entering each day. Fort Station is the main rail gateway to central Colombo; it is the terminus of most intercity trains in the country https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_railway_station

British built Central Railway Station with the Train seat Booking centre located for tickets to all parts of Sri Lanka . The typical British type construction prevails reminding one of the days gone by . The Railway Museum in the vicinity is interesting . Room for improvement and cleanliness despite the thousands who patronize the station daily .

I have used Colombo Fort Rail station twice and it has been fine.  I live in London so it might be that I am not intimidated by crowds rushing but using the ticket service and finding the correct platform and train seat was very simple.  Train travel is a very convenient and cheap way to travel through Sri Lanka.  We travelled in the very early morning commuter trains (we had small hand luggage bags) and it was a very pleasant experience even in second class.  We would happily do it again, infact we are planning to use trains for our next visit. We took a car from Colombo to Kandy for 800 Sri Lankan rupees and then on the return journey we took a train for back via Colombo to Hikkaduwe   which is far south of Colombo and paid 180 SL rupees for train tickets both of us.

Because of the many people at the front of the station it becomes a bit difficult to pull luggage along. But that is only outside. Nobody gets in without a valid ticket. Signage is done in English as well. One should take note of the know how to use the train on the island. A bit annoying is the fact that there are no elevators yet.

i have gone on train to visit many places like Kandy, Badulla, Anuradhapura, Matara and Jaffna using the Sri Lankan railway service. it is low cost and a very efficient way to view the beauty of Sri Lanka. you could travel to several destinations in luxury and at a low rate using the Expo Rail; see here: http://www.exporail.lk/

One of the busy places in Colombo is Railway and the Bus Stand , Been low income and mid range people use to travel the railway to avoid the bus root traffic and reasonable rate in the ticket fees. Not much attraction to the tourism but good to know the people struggle  that they going through in there day today life. This not an attraction point of view , but good to know about the anthropology of the Sri Lankan and better to make a train tour to hill country for difference experience. I'm quit sure this is better than Indian railway.

The station itself is very very basic. However this post is in relation for tourists using the 'tourist information' which is not just for information but booking travel. We used this for our travels around Sri Lanka, as had a lot of distance to cover in not that much time (2 weeks). Now we may have been slightly done of the price (70 pounds per person for 5). But our trip included and a/c van and driver for Colombo to hikkaduwa then to aruganbay, ella and then to kandy. We also had an OBSERVATION carriage booked for the beautiful train ride from Ella to Nanuoya as well. All dealt through Prasanna Ferdinando (tour assistant) we were happy for the majority of the package. However, he tried to screw us for a little extra. Firstly, lying about the exchange rate (he called the bank to to prove he was right and shown to be completely and utterly wrong). This was to gain that little extra from us which he gave up on as he said we had given the him a 'headache' (all very embarrassing and rude). Secondly, instead of buying the tickets for the observation carriage for the later part of the trip in Ella (1000 rupees each ticket), he got us the 3rd class tickets (400 rupees each or less). Finding this out a couple of days before, a stern call to Prasanna meant out driver bought the tickets and gave them to us when he returned to pick out bags us at Ella while we got the train. That said our driver was a legend and a good laugh. This made up for poor experience with Prasanna.
located right in the middle of city centre with bus terminal just beside it that makes this area crowded and messy

Its Extremely dirty, Very poorly maintained. most of the trains are dirty as well, people just push you over and rush in to 2nd class cabins no order. Staff is lethargic, not properly trained or dressed and unfriendly. One of the worst places in Colombo, an upgrade is a MUST!!!

We took the train from Colombo to Kandy with all of our luggage. Go to booth 17 and book for the first class to make it easy - a whole £5 each for an approx 3 hour journey. The seats reclined and moved apart from the one next to them to give more space. Very helpful chaps serving mugs of tea and pastries. With free wi-fi and a film! our train didn't have the observation car sadly. There are separate toilets on the platform for "foreigners", but the loo on the train was fine. I didn't see anyone on the roof of any trains, but plenty hanging out of open doors! If you can remember diesel trains being shunted up the line to change direction, this station will bring back memories. Pettah market is opposite, and there's a clothing market next door.

When we visited Sri Lanka, this train station was a bit of a hub for us.  We had to make several stops, and one departure through this train station, and each time we commuted it was a learning experience.  The first thing we learned was don't trust anybody when it came to where your train was leaving, sometimes not even your ticket.  The only people that seemed to know which platform our train was leaving was a group of def people that would help you find your train, and help with your bags, then demand a large tip. Cleanliness was also a second thought in this station, it was so bad that I didn't dare use the bathrooms from the smell alone. There also isn't much as far as places to get snacks or a meal if you're transferring.  Best to go outside and enjoy some of the street kiosks if you can instead. Security was also pretty non-existent, unless you're a traveler. It seems that if you have a bag, a ticket, and look confused security will stop and make sure you're not breaking into the station.  However if you're a random person selling something, a scam artist, illegal cab driver, or any other person you're welcome to come in no questions asked. The reason this station doesn't get a completely poor review is that it's a pretty nice building.  Under the layers of dust it's pretty interesting.  I took a few pictures there that really are spectacular.  Notionally you'll need a train ticket to take these pictures, but if you don't have a ticket, security might just let you through anyways.

If you have the time and like the countryside, you must take a trip on the railways from Colombo Fort. Just recently travelled myself. What an experience from Colombo to Nuwarayo. Was on way to Little England "Nuwara Eliya". Absolutely beautiful scenery. Cost was 2200rupee's 1st.class with meal and drinks. Took aprox 6hrs and loved every minute of it.......You'll certainly enjoy the experience. Cheers!!

On the first day of our trip, we went to the Colombo Fort Railway's tourist information office. The manager Prassana helped us with scheduling our itinerary and providing a private driver for the whole trip (7 days). Lahiru was our driver's name and we couldn't imagine having another driver than him. He took his time to stop at every interesting places and explain a lot of things concerning the Sri Lankan culture. He provided all the help we needed during our vacation across Sri Lanka. I highly recommend Prassana's tour and ask for Lahiru if possible!

Despite the overwhelming first impression, it's easy to get to grips with this place. Yes it's busy, noisy and hot, nothing to make you feel unsafe though. Helpful railway tourist office gave us clear and helpful information and advice on the trains to Galle. Finding which platform was quite straight forward, always a helpful person to point you in the right direction, they always make me suspicious thinking they want something in return, they don't and are just being helpful (and making me feel guilty afterwards for thinking everyone is trying to rip us off). The interior of the station is quite grey and drab. Very noisy with trains coming and going as you would expect. The journey to Galle was great though. We got the first class tourist train. Was t much first class about it though other than aircon (that didn't work) and am assigned seat. No food or drinks on the train so be aware and come prepared. The journey was great though and the fact the aircon wasn't working was actually good as meant we could open the windows and get a much better view of the lovely costal scenery. Really recommend the Journey and a trip by train if you are in Colombo and want to get out of town.

We arrived to colombo by train. The structure is interesting to see and well worth a visit if you happen to be there. There is even a little aquarium in the wall of platform 3. You can only enter the platforms with a ticket. From the outside it had some charme, but I liked the inside more. Go when you have to be there, but it's not really worth a big detour.

Like many colonial-era buildings, the railway station is neglected. It's a shame and with a good restoration could be a very attractive and important landmark. Avoid the toilets at all cost. If you are arriving in Colombo and are a foreigner, you will be accosted by a the tuk-tuk drivers, all claiming they'll give you a good deal. Most of them do NOT have meters, and you should avoid them altogether; the prices they offer you are typically double what a metered tuk-tuk would charge. Some tuk-tuks have meters, but the drivers will tell you that they are out of order; they say they will give you "meter price" but don't believe it. Some will also wave a certificate in your face saying they are "Official Fort Railway Station" registered or some such nonsense. Be aware that this means absolutely nothing. Keep in mind that there is an unofficial mafia of sorts, that controls who gets to pick up customers at the station, and any driver not part of this monopoly is forced to park off the property. As with anywhere in Colombo, if you get a metered cab, make sure they turn them on when you start to make sure they actually do work. If you can't find a good tuk-tuk, or your red-flags are flying (always follow your instincts) the thing to do is, upon leaving the station, walk to your left; there are huge numbers of tuk-tuks parked on the street; these guys are generally more honest than the cabal which controls the station parking lot.

Main station in Colombo for all trains.  Not as hectic as otsher stations we have been to in many other places.  Good to arrive early for onward journey to become orientated but all platforms easy to find.
Can get a train to lot of areas In Sri Lanka from this station and easy to find out in Colombo Fort.

The Fort Railway station is the central train station in Colombo with direct services to the main provincial towns such as Kandy, Jaffna and Nuwara Eliya. The station is near the Pettah which is a busy and bustling market place, well worth exploring. The station itself has seen better days and could do with some TLC.

This Railways Station is the main Fort Railway In Colombo to take different part of the city to travel a small Tourist information office available, need more computerize system to be update specially for tourist. its not well maintain. need more care an attention.

The station is in the Pettah area which is a wonderful crazy, busy market. Spent a couple of hours wandering around and being assailed by the noise and general chaos - wonderful if you want to break away from traditional tourist activities

The Colombo fort railway station functions in a very old not so big colonial structure.  The premises was crowded all the time.  Outside is the roadside bus terminus from where buses can be had to different part of Colombo city. An important junction for both trains and buses in Colombo.
Its the main Railway station of Colombo from where you can get Sub Urban and Long Distance Trains... Located in the heart of Colombo...Old Colonial Building...

The toilets are not to be recommended . Please try to do your business elsewhere before coming here . As a railway station its  much the same as most  stations .It would have some charm it an effort was made to preserve /highlight its colonial structures and put up some  interesting information  on its heritage.

This is a very busy station. You need to allow yourself some time to find out where you should be to catch your train. I went for a walk there the day before I was due to leave for Jaffna. this gave me a chance to soak up the atmosphere, check that the departure time on my ticket was still correct ( it wasn't), and for 20 rupees buy a platform ticket so that I could have a look around. People were helpful and friendly and I had no problems finding the right platform. I travelled to Galle from here also, and arrived from Ella. The trains are very good and very cheap.

From the Colombo Fort Railway Station we took the train to Kandy. It took us like 10 minutes to find the right Gate... As soon as the train arrived, everyone ran to get a place- luckily we booked some private seats! At the trains door was a man, telling us where our seats are (thought this was a staff member...) but as soon as everyone was sitting, he went around, signing that he is deaf, working in a deaf school and wants/needs money... no problem- but the way he did was just unreasenable! We gave him 1000 Rupees but then he looked as this wasnt enough for him!

At this station, they can arrange Any trip you want to do!!!!! We did it all and it was FANTASTIC!!!!!! Prasanna Ferdinando arranged a 10 day trip for us- listening carefully what we wanted and in 20 minutes, we had a complete tour with all the highlights we wanted. Very efficient, relaxed and friendly and very knowledgable. Very affordable and... With a driver. Never had a driver before... Well, we had Lahiru Dissanayaka:  a true gem! Very well driving- I felt save All the time, friendly, humor, easy- whatever we wanted to do, where ever we wanted to go: all was possible! If we had no idea: he had one!!! He made our trip so comfortable... Traveling had never been so easy! And no way could we have driven it all our selves. Traffic is totally hectic compared to European standards and signs aren't readable. I can So recommend Rail Tours and Lahiru: you will have a GREAT trip!!!
The train station staff were very helpful and. Took time to ensure we had the right time and platform for our train

Going thru the train station was an easy and pleasant experience. Arrived well in advance finding the platform was a non issue and mixing in the morning life a real delight. Catching the train was also easy and helped by locals if needed be. The place is a paradise for photographers catching local life in morning light.
We were here on Sunday 10th April to catch train to Kandy. Good decorated station. We exchange our e ticket for EXPORAIL. Ticket counter within a AC room.(Counter 7) Nice and cooperative staff.

Train travel whilst in Sri Lanka is a must.  Much more pleasant than catching the buses but having continuity in ticket prices and bookings does not exist.  First class gives you air conditioning and generally a seat (not too crowded) but best to only have carry-on luggage.  Third class is as many people as possible in.  There are loads of deaf people who come to the station to help tourists find their way around.  They then expect donations for their services.

What can I say about Colombo’s Fort Railway station other then, if you have only been to a train station in a developed country then you are in for a shock!  The way to enjoy it is to just go with the flow.  The station itself is easy to find and all tuk-tuk drivers know where it is. The station has many ticket counters, all numbered, and above which is a list of places they stop and the cost.  If in doubt go to counters 6 or 7 which are the inquiry counters where you can get help.  We travelled on the Sri Lankan trains to Hikkaduwa, Galle, Kandy and Negombo and had no problems at all finding the train times and getting the correct trains.  500 or 1000 LKR notes are best for the ticket counters as the train prices are very cheap in Sri Lanka.  Once you have your ticket go through the entrance and there is a large screen which will tell you the platform number, it changes between Sri Lanka and English every 30 seconds or so. When on the correct platform you can ask a member of staff which end of the platform the carriages for 2nd or 3rd class will arrive.  Once the train starts to appears pick you bags up and get ready for the rush to the door.  There will not be any manners shown, so it will be every man, woman and child for yourself. (No different to ‘rush’ hour at any station in the world).  Keep your ticket as you will need to hand it in when you get off the train. The trains are heavily used in Sri Lanka so if you are slow getting on you may not have a seat.  If so, and you don’t mind standing, you can stand by the open carriage doors which is a great way to see the country side pass by. We didn’t use the website instead just went to the station to book the tickets. PS. Try to get an ‘express’ train rather than a ‘slow’ train as they are slow.

What a fiasco. Make sure to have small bills (money) . They seldom have change for bigger denominations. Always ask a train attendant where the train is coming from.... Or departing from to eliminate confusion. Keep your ticket! Will need it when exiting station. If you are planning on taking a tuk Tuk when you arrive...  Do NOT take one from the front of the station.  They do not have fare meters and their prices are sky high. Just walk 50 feet or so to the main road and hail a taxi from there.  99% of the tuk Tuk 's in Colombo has fare meters.  The other 1% is at the railway station. Lol. The toilets are extremely dirty. So try and hold it in.

The Sri Lankan railway has a website and claims that you can make on-line bookings but it doesn't work.  The station is filthy, crowded and the service is terrible. The trains too are filthy.  You have to go through these stations even to board the Expolanka Luxury trains. It's just not worth it. A few meters north of the Station the intercity Bus stand with air-conditioned buses await to take you to all cities in the country. The fare is only a fraction of the luxury train fare. For example the Luxury train is Rs. 1,500 to kandy where as the Air-conditioned bus costs only Rs 300. 3rd class train travel is the cheapest but don't even think of the 2nd class train compartments. Most aren't air conditioned and even the fans don't work. And the 2nd class fare is an absolute rip off for a mismanaged national railway system. Wonder what the half a dozen or so Ministers of Transport are upto

The main Railway station of the country. Not amazingly well organized, but it really is well organized on kind of a level. You can grab a quick bite, breakfast of snacks at the railway(saves you time). And the tickets are much cheaper compared to other transportation methods.

We used the Colombo Fort Railway Station to travel to Kandy. We had already reserved seats online but as you need to exchange the online booking confirmation for tickets to travel we had to wait for the sales desk to open. We arrived at 6am (our train was scheduled to leave at 7am). The sales office opened at 6am but no one came to the desk until 0640hrs! There was a mad dash and lots of pushing and shoving but we did manage to get our tickets and the staff on the platform and on the train were very helpful.
The only reason to visit us if you are arriving or leaving by train. It is old and very congested. Outside you are approached by many TukTuk drivers offering to drive you.

Amazing way to view the hustle and bustle of Sri Lanka. The 2nd class trains are pretty stuffy and from where I boarded (Colombo) I did not manage to get any seats. Had  to stand for 2.5 hours to get to Bentota. Not ideal for families or kids. Ideal for backpackers for travellers on a budget . Tickets are really affordable though. TIP: Go to the railway station to check on the tickets. Online site does not help.

As far as stations go, for tourists, this station could really be improved. Upon entry you get told verbally where to catch your train, but there are no signs on the platforms telling you which train departs where. I started to worry when someone asked me if we were catching a train to a different place, I was worried we were not on the right platform. It was early in the morning when we visited, so did not get a chance to take photos, but it is pretty old and I'm sure if you go in the day it might be a good place for some decent photos.
there is a local market next to it which makes this place a must visit, never went inside the station, but the local market was very cheap.
The authorities can improve by heaps. Not maintained clean. Staff are complacent. Not friendly at service.

The minute one walks into the Fort Railway Station you are transported 50 years or so back. It was built in 1908 and did not appear to have had any upgrading work done. I was told it had 10 platforms and steps and a bridge connecting to these. One modern aspect is the display screen but one could not trust whether the information was accurate. It was very noisy, sometimes painful to the ear as each train entered and left the platform. One could hardly hear the other speaking. Maybe I am old and sensitive to this noise. There were security/ticket checkers sitting at entry and exit points. However it was easy to push through the crowds and enter the station without any checking. Inside the station, there were some seats but not enough for the number of passengers waiting. Our train was to Jaffna leaving at 5.45 am. I wanted to check something about my ticket. There were no information or ticket counters inside. However there was a room where several men were seated behind their desks. There were no computers, everything done manually. If you expect western standards you may think the men were not interested and unhelpful. However, this is the way it seems things are in Srilanks, there are no queues and people tend to push with the 'me first' attitude. I did get my answers to my questions but also advice that one of the trains I had booked my return journey was a slow train taking 10 hours. I was grateful for this information and was able to change my ticket. Unlike airports there are porters to help with your luggage I did not see any porters here. I actually loved this antique railway station.

To start with: don't think of just going and grab a ticket for a train ride to Kandy (or anywhere in Sri Lanka I think). Be prepared and get your tickets well in advance. We got our return journey from Colombo to Kandy and startet on a Saturday morning at 7 am towards Kandy. Had a reservation in the Expo Rail and in general it is worth it. On our return from Kandy the air conditioning was not working and it became a sweating exercise. They serve water, coffee, tea and snacks in that category and it's included in the price. The journey is around 2.5 hours and compare to a drive in a car it's the faster way to Kandy. The tide itself is bumpy and the train does not go to fast. Once in a lifetime you should try this out. The train stations in Sri Lanka are nothing much to write home about.

This station does not have the flair what it should have from the old times,however one can see the busy life in a capital city's main station Old locs and trainswhich would go with the place are missing. Very helpful staff  at the station and  for round trips in the country try railway tours organising rail+drive tours with reasonable price and reliable drivers. They have their office next to the main entrance

Took the train from Mount Lavinia to here which was an experience in itself, people were hanging out of the open doors, the seats had holes in them.....literally. On getting off the train at Colombo Fort I was struck by the dirt and what felt like general lack of maintenance.

First of all the, old colonial look is not well maintained , smell of urine is rampant and thus makes you wanna vomit. The Old miserable geezers who checks tickets behave like they wanna kill themselves . no helpful signs are in place to facilitate stranded tourists. all the garbage is thrown in to tracks without much concern. cleaning staff is unheard of and pretty much non-existent concept here. Ticketing officers seem to fed up their jobs and take their stress out of local commuters but would wag their tails delightfully at foreigners. Not recommended to stat for a longer periods.
Quite unhygienic but can survive.. Do not buy food items from the street vendors and travel in crowds and not safe for women in the evening

The station area is clean, inside and in front, that is very good comparing to stations I have been to f.ex. in India. I also felt safe during my time waiting for the train to Jaffna. Still I was glad that I didn`t need to use the bathroom or had to eat in a restaurant.
And this isn't one. But it is charming and fascinating enough to take you eye off the obvious deficiencies. Trains leave to many of the favourite tourist destinations all over SL.

This central Station is loud, dirty, inefficient and weird. But it's awesome. Brings back memories of past years (Centuries) of Rail Travel. I actually "Starred" in a recent Bollywood movie with my daughter, set in Bombay in the 1950's. They chose to film the scenes here, in Colombo Fort Station. With me? maybe ;-) But because it still is authentic, quaint and looks like India a century ago .... Go and have a stroll around! It should cost you only a platform ticket - but as there is a shortcut tru the entire station to another main road (Lake House Rd & Int. Parcel Service Office) nobody seems to bother with that.

Very old style rail station. Does the job but if the waiting time is more then it is real pain. It is clean though and you get drinking water bottles and some snacks. There was a oldish restaurant but we did not check it out.
Still this place should be more improved. especially wash rooms. some time back they were collecting money from the users of wash rooms and there was no any significant improvement.
If you want to catch up on diverse set of people - this is the place. Found this place to be not very crowded. Liked the attraction from outside more though.

You can find a train for Kandy,Negombo,Galle,Anuradhapura,Jaffna from here. Luxury trains with AC also are available here to serve you. Take care about your valuables from the world's no1 thieves outside the station.

I'm not sure if there is a quiet period at Colombo Fort railway station, we changed here in a couple of journeys and it was always busy. It is more developed than some other stations in Sri Lanka with free WiFi and an electronic departure board. Some of the trains are extremely packed similar to rush hour on the tube, but more so, with passengers hanging out of the doors. However, unlike the tube you don't have to just put up for a few minutes - we were standing, squashed and sweating for two hours to Galle. It is fascinating to see the dilapidated looking carriages and engines.

We came into this railway station a few times and found it both challenging and charming.  I decided to write this review because after 30 years of riding trains in India and Sri Lanka, we learned something so basic we were dumbfounded.  If your bag has wheels you don't have to carry it up the steps and back down to cross over the platforms.  At the end of the platforms there are flat crossovers!  Sometimes it's a bit of a schlep, but it beats doing it the old way.  Oh, and unlike India, we have never seen a porter at rail stations in Sri Lanka.  Who says you can't teach old dogs new tricks?

This being the most common 'first Sri Lankan railway experience' for most travellers, the staff are quite helpful in where to send you for tickets/reservations. The locals are also willing to help you out if you are looking lost! The signage is easy to come across and with Pettah Markets just across the road you can get some cheap food and shopping before you head off.

Unfortunately Srilanka railway authorities has not done justice to this main railway station of the country built in the colonial era. It is undoubtedly the starting point for some of worlds great railway journeys yet the station it self lack infrastructure, good clean amenities, and general maintenance. Access to the station by public transport could be improved with some parking facilities in the vicinity. The building itself has character of a bygone era however neglected. This is only the station, do not be put off to take a train journey from herer to the hill capital Kandy, or beyond to the central hills of Badulla. The the coastal line or the recently restored Jaffna line.
Our Son developped dharrea, he wanted to go to the toilet at asap...to the foreighner's toilet. The toilet was (& is Locked I believe..) is locked with a paddlock.   JOKE of the CENTURY....

Crowded, busy, bustling with activity, the station also holds a hidden secret, and azurveda pharmacy complete with prescribing parmacists whose English is limited but will likely understand you right.  Helped solve my sore throat problem.  It is located one of  the platforms. Despite the chaos, access is easy and people are remarkably helpful.
Taxi took us right to door step. Well sign posted in English. We too the Expo Rail service which was comfortable although the ride was very shaky. Service on the train good and was on time.

Arrived at this old working railway station to access market areas (Pettah, Aslam and Federation of Self-Employees markets) and other attractions like the Red Mosque, Old town Hall, Wolvendaal Church all nearby.  The old Fort railway station is charming with many original architectural features.

If you want to see Sri Lanka then you must take three train rides one to Kandy the ancient capital the other to Newra Eliya and the other trip to Galle all along the coast be prepared for a trip of over 21/2 hours ,the trip to Kandy will take just as long as they stop at every station and its an event in itself with all the hawkers offering you all sorts of short eats , you can get first class seats or do the backpacker thing and go with the natives the train is always full so you can end up standing all the way the scenery is breathtaking and the trip to Nera Eliya 69000 feet up is a  must its just one of those things you need to add to the 100 list befor you depart this beautiful earth the only living planet in our solar system. do not worry you will return to dust from which you came and  be resting till the resurrection .

The old station is interesting, like most stations it is busy with mostly locals.  We traveled first class to Kandy, not quite what the photos showed on the website but still a good way to get to Kandy cheaply.

train services are great and so cheap it cost us 30p return for a 40 min journey for two of us , just outside the station are lots of market stalls selling everything from sandals to shirts etc , plenty of tuk tuks outside  to get you around

Colombo Fort Railway Station is amazing. Busy, a frenzy of people going somewhere. Station masters in Colonial uniform which for anyone of a certain age can recognise from their childhood experiences when travelling by train was considered a journey. First impression could be described as chaotic but it works. The ticket counters are efficient and straight forward. The trains run on time obviously punctuality is highly regarded and the station master with his whistle is there to control things. The trains are something else and should be considered as part of the travel experience. Don't expect the Japanese Bullet train, AMTRAK or European services but great fun and something that you will be talking about in your postcards home. Even if you are not travelling anywhere Colombo Fort Railway Station is worth a visit just to absorb the atmosphere of locals travelling.
The station is not that special architecturally but is a great place for people watching and soaking up atmosphere.

It is just like a Railway Station like Mumbai's CST Raillway.  But certainly not that great archiitrctural value.  The surroundings are just like any of the moderately big Railway Stations in India, surrounded with shops, eateries etc.
Very neat and clean Railway system.The trains are very good and the station is basic but with very friendly and helpful locals
Starting point for the trains and a terminus. Very crowded especially during office hours. Easily accessible though. There are markets near by.
This station is a turning point for plenty of srilankan's and foreigners as well. :)   Be careful with you wallets and devices :)

I frequently visit here to pick friends and to travel. Although outside of the station is a bit awkward inside is quite clean and you will only be disturbed by the announcements from time to time. I even used to read books and do stuff on my laptop seated on the 9th & 10th platforms when trains were late. You need to buy a platform ticket for Rs.10/- to enter the railway station to pick someone or even to say goodbye. There's a bookshop inside the station where you will find things with info on Sri Lanka. The setback of the premises is huge and nice. They have maintained it in a superb way keeping flower pots and stuff.
It looks old but attractive and having a old days charm from outside. As loke other railways stations it was crowded but we enjoyed even in the rain.
Very tired, rundown station lacking almost every facility you should expect . Do not linger! Serious investment need ed.

If you've never been to a South Asian country, then this station epitomised everything that is chaotic and fun about them. There are actually signs for destinations, for times and prices. For Kandy, go to counter 17. Facilities and information are South Asian average. There's plenty of eateries of questionable hygiene just outside the station as well as tuck took drivers ready to rip off tourists. Trains are slow and always late, and runs a close battle with buses for for second place as an means of efficient point to point travel in Sri Lanka.

Organising a ticket from outside Sri Lanka ie booking online would have been great but not possible from Australia so fortunately Reddot kindly helped us book ahead  but even then we'd hoped for a sleeper but got the seats . We've caught trains , tuk tuks and buses in various Asian countries but what struck me was the station was like entering a mine and I was ready to send my canary in first ! .. poor poor lighting so I was happy to notice a women's waiting room as I'd be a little cautious  if a lone female traveller  due to the darkness although of course as we found throughout Sri Lanka people are very friendly . locating the right train was a little challenging and although very old trains they were clean with clean toilets . The train stops here. And there for mail pick up/ drop off  and at one pint stopped 20 minutes where the local vendors wait for train travellers to sell there food. The hot drink vendor calls along the train " teacoffeeteacoffeeteacoffee" . Bottled water also available from vendor . If you're only going to Polonnarawu you'll need to book a night at a close hotel as the train arrives around 1:30 am so don't anticipate too much sleep on the night train but it's an easy way to get to visit the Cultural Triangle and beyond ... Just make sure you can find your train in the dark .
The Colombo Fort Railway is easily accessible by buses from various parts of the city. Once you're here, you can easily purchase tickets to wherever your next destination is...

This the main railway station in Sri Lanka, except for the coastal line all other trains starts from here. this can consider as the most cheapest method of traveling in Sri Lanka. you can check the train schedule via their official website. For booking you can call them or visit the station booking center and get you bookings done. fr information it is quite hard to contact them via telephone. Be advised, going by bus is faster sometimes even though its not cheap as train rides.

Not a place you need to visit unless you want to travel by train. Train travel is safe and inexpensive so I would recommend visiting the station for that reason. You can travel to the historic town of Galle in three hours in the early morning and catch the afternoon train back to Colombo for an easy one day trip out of Colombo.
Sadly it is very dirty , looks like never been cleaned. Always trying not to pass by colombo fort railway station

since 18 th century. british people build colonial style station. for any destination to start trainne journes start from this place. 24 hrs open. affter enter this place not very clean and maintaining.specialy monday to friday morning 7am to 9am &  evening 4 pm to 7pm sooooo busy.......

For the foreign traveller arriving first time at Fort Railway station, looking for luxury travel may have to rethink again! Fort is hot and chaotic and once you enter the railway station, one cannot escape the experience outside to the similar experience inside.  There is a sense of urgency about everything and yet without the rush. Trains depart to a different timetable to the listed departure time adding a memorable experience to your travels, but not if you are in a hurry to get to work! The good news is that in the midst of all the hustle & bustle, the system works. The best part of the train journey is chugging along the scenic coastal route. I urge any traveller who is brave enough to take a train ride from Fort to various island destinations to experience the train ride as well as enjoy the sites along the coastal route. If you are brave enough, you can also taste various local food carried up and down the carriages by local food traders.  Taking a train journey from Colombo Fort, should be a mandatory experience by all travellers!
It is an Old railway station and seen along the roadside. The structure represents the time of construction.

Very busy train station where you need to buy your ticket from the ticket office first as you can't enter without one. Make sure you double check your platform on the board which is in English too. Beware of con artists trying to get you to give them cash for their deaf school. This is a scam and they are already being paid for helping travellers.
Took some time to visit here, very busy station with some health and safety issues, interesting to see how the locals commute.
Must see place in Colombo.You can see how the old work of Royal Railway and Sri Lanka Railway. All the trains start from this point heading to southern, northern and hill country.

After a month of traveling by train in Myanmar, where train workers were super helpful, we encountered the ticket people at Colombo's train station, some of the rudest and unhelpful workers we encountered on our three month journey through Asia. It's confusing which counter you go to ... and once we bought our tickets to Matara, and caught the train a day or two after, we were chagrined to discover the train was already full when it arrived to the Central Station, and we had to stand a long time. Not the entire way, but until a good many people got off. It seemed like a typical experience. No one seemed surprised, and other reviewers mention it, too, in their reviews. The train station is in about the same area as the bus station, which makes for major traffic congestion, depending on when you go. The good news is this was the most annoying train station (I think) we encountered in Sri Lanka, so if you successfully maneuver this obstacle, it's downhill all the way.

If you have already planned your stay you should be fine, it is an average rail station. However if you are a tourist who looks remotely lost you will be escorted to a local travel agency where they will meticulously help you plan your trip and then inflate the price a ridiculous amount. Please don't make the same mistake we made.

The pedestrian bridge for entering from cross the road was very dirty but story do not end here. The station was so much badly maintained that there was so much confusion due to motion of crowd in different directions. They need to meet international standards to compete with other international tourist destinations.

We were determined to ride the Sri Lankan railway from Colombo to Matara - we were able to book 2nd Class tickets about an hour before the train was due to leave but we still ended up standing for 21/2 hours of the 31/2 hours jouney. The station is old and in need of a facelift but has the typical character of colonial railway buildings - rivets everywhere in the roof structure. It is not possible to get on to the platforms unless you are travelling by train and so 'sightseeing' is not available - but to be honest  - not much to see!!

And on top of that it is also a beautiful old building with old clocks and other old remnants. Worth a visit even if you are not traveling (you can enter from the tracks then). As a train station things a pretty straight forward - it is working and there is a large also English written departure and arrival board, so foreigners can also find the right track and time of their train.

Well, it was not their fault for being on strike precisely the day we got there, but the place could do with a lot more cleaning and organizing... Too much dirt and disorganizing to take in from the very first day in Sri Lanka, I'm afraid. Still, if you want to travel by train to Kandy- the best way to take in the fabulous scenery- this is the station to go to.
In desperate need for an upgrade. If you need to get a ticket of long out station journeys you need to look for the door at the far end (pettah end) of the front of the station.

From here you can go across the sri lanka cheaply but please avoid the washrooms and the floor is cleaner than all most every other thing here. Bring your own food and other stuff and take care of your belongings and late trains.

Fort Railway station encapsulates Sri Lanka - very functional but chaotic to the uninitiated. Signeage is very poor and the so called tourist information office is pathetic - one feels like one is entering a time warp going throughout the door. As rail travel especially amongst tourists is on the increase in SL, Fort railway station really needs to up it's game if it is to cater for a new type of customer.

This is the Oldest Railway station in Sri Lanka. Initiated in 1864, sandwiched between two roads namely Henry Steel Olcott Mawatha and  MacCallum Road. A small peninsula in the Beira Lake. Very old Victorian architecture is visible but with very poor or no maintenance. Recent developments to the Railway platforms are encouraging. Communication system is very hash, blurred and unclear. Smelly toilets and unfriendly staff. Ticket counter clerks are caged in like monkeys and throw the tickets and change to the travelers. Not customer friendly or Oriented. Very poorly maintained. Rail tracks are full of used tickets,paper.empty PVC bottles etc, Cleaning had not being done for years.Very old photographs are sited in wrong places, difficult to enjoy them as crowds gather there to exit. Improper or no layout plans is playing a big role here.

this is the railway station after mount lavinia if you are planning to explore the island nation by train. I visited this station since I was travelling to Jaffna by train and boarded my train from this station. as compared to Indian stations these are still backdated. there is no proper announcement system, there are no LCD/ LED indicators indicating which train is arriving when and which platform, the rake positions etc. But it will add up in due course of time I hope. the station exteriors are not that clean as is the rest of the city.
The main station I regularly commute. Station is pretty okay. There are some vendors,cafeteria and men's and women's. But the smells from the washrooms can not be bearable everyday.

We were expecting the worst based on the mixed reviews on TA but to our surprise it was ok. The station was clean, very busy and hot with very few amenities. Signs are not cleared but there are enquiries counters which will aptly guide you. For our case, we were directed to counter no 17 (berth/intercity/reservation/Expo Rail) which essentially is a small air conditioning room. Inside this room, just queue at the respective ticket counter. We showed our pre booked Expo Rail reservation no on mobile (no print out required) and our boarding ticket issued. In fact you can pickup the pre booked Expo Rail boarding ticket before your scheduled departure from 6am-4pm daily (note: counter 17 close lunch time 12.30pm-1pm). Aside on Expo Rail was excellent. Clean, comfortable A/C ride, with free wifi, clean toilet, snacks, bottled water and movie. Heading towards Kandy on Coach 3, best seat 2, 4, 10 on the right with big window. Others have 2 smaller windows. Seat 5 has no window. 3 star for the station, 5 star for Expo Rail.

We walked to the station, asked where to buy a train ticket and got pointed in the right direction. Five minutes later I had our 2nd class tix to Kandy for a few bucks. Easy as pie and the train arrived and departed on time. It is a long bumpy ride but you will have some great scenery to enjoy as well as people to meet on the train.

Prasanna organised a tour around Sri Lanka with the best driver ever.  Professional, knowledgeable  about political and cultural situation.  We are delighted we found them.  First experience with a driver for us and it made our stay so very enjoyable.  We saw much more of Sri Lanka than we expected to see in the time we spent there.  Highly recommend this service. PS we left a charger behind in one hotel and rail tours organised the return for us!

Train station with lots of movement. initially seems to be very confusing, but the staff give good information, if we are lost with so many counters to buy tickets. The station is also located near the bus station and has commerce around.

The railway station has its own beauty and attractiveness. The booking clerks are efficient, fares are exceedingly low, trains are very frequent on the busier lines such as to Mt Lavinia while passengers do not push and shove too much. For some trains to secure a seat it can be best to board at Maradana if that is an option.  Reserving a seat is better but not possible for every train. On platform one there are good kiosks selling snacks, drinks and other requisites.  The language barrier can be present, so try to look for a man dressed in a suit or a well dressed woman as they are the ones more likely to comprehend English.
went to see th e busiest place in colombo the indian and SBI are there. and people are pouring in all roads. the traffic is well controlled and so it is easy for hr pedestrais to cross the road.

We caught the Galle to Colombo Fort train on 4th Feb which was independence day.  We hadn't been able to reserve a seat on this train, and was somewhat suprised by the numbers milling about on the platform!  We had a 2 - 3 hr journey, standing up with no room whatsovever.  apparently this was the end of a long bank holiday and the earlier train had been cancelled. At the Col Fort station we had a nightmare trying to find the Negombo highway bus, as it is extremely chaotic and there are about 5 bus stations.  Do your research before you travel.

I am going to take a deep breath with this one - 'cultural shock' is an understatement.  We visited in the evening during the hours of darkness after quite a long walk around the actual Fort and the massive hotel/base for navy personnel. Here was I naive enough to think that I could just buy a ticket, get on a train and arrive at my destination. First you have to find the right ticket office. There are many each selling tickets to various places. Don't even think of credit cards which are by the way generally not liked. This is due to high commissions when every Rp. is needed. Anyway we eventually were directed to the right booth and got a single ticket to Mt Lavinia for the princely sum of Rp 10 (UKP 0.05). We entered the station and there our dystopian (opposite of utopian)  experience began. They have obviously decided to save money by using low wattage 500 mHz bulbs. These white LED type lights don't have any ooompph so the whole reminded me of what Victoria England under the gas lights might have been like. We were directed to Platform 5. Fair enough. A train came in which we found through asking was the Express to Galle. I could swear it stopped at our destination station but the verdict from people was that the next train was the one. The express train arrived at 6.40 and people immediately got on. So far so good. However the train showed no signs of moving. To cut a long story short it departed at 7.30 pm. A train is not full unless at least six people were hanging out of each door and this proved to be the case. When the train starts to pull out off the station people were still running down the stairs and jumping on. Maybe it pulls out slowly for this reason. So, 'our' train is due to depart 7.50 pm. No sign. If you hope for indicator signs there was one on our platform but not working. It's that little word 'maintenance' which is missing from the vocabulary. It was bought and paid for so end of story. There is one brightly illuminated  departure board in three languages (Tamil, English and Sinhala the local language) but the information is not updated and the refresh rate is so high that it is impossible to read. As for asking people - that's hit and miss. Most locals have not been outside their own country. Europe and European languages are totally unfamiliar to them so quite frankly we might as well come from another planet. This is confusing as the locals are so polite that they nod and smile to anything you say but they don't have the faintest idea of what you are talking about.  Even 'does this train go to Mt. Lavinia' is too much for 90% of people. Tip - look for someone well dressed. They are more likely to be educated in languages and be able to help. Oh, and don't expect to see the destination on the front of the train or on the sides. Look for the train number plate on the engine for clues as to where it is going. You might want to avoid the bathrooms. Anyway, the 7.50 pm train never turned up so at 8 pm we left and took a Tuk Tuk down to our base.  BTW Tuk Tuks wont break the bank. For example a 3 km ride will set you back less than Rp. 160  0.80UKP. More of Tuk Tuks later If you want to read about all my adventures you can get to them via my user name on the left of this page.  I am open for questions.   19 Feb 2015

It's a must see only to reminisce on how things used to be when rail was king of travel.  The architecture, signage and bureaucracy of the station is from a bygone age. The station it's self though is difficult to comprehend albeit the staff are helpful, no info boards for train platforms and the toilets are disgraceful. We took an overnight to Polonaruwa 1st Class cabin was basically next to a septic tank!!! 2nd Class is better when trains aren't busy. Try it, enjoy it for what it is, but I couldn't use this station daily it's too chaotic!

To travel by train is a turistic attraction in Sri Lanka. Than why not to start here. You can buy cheap and expensive tickets here - there are turist agencies for special trains here. The building of the railway station is nothing extra, but this is the main train station to everywhere - than a goog starting point to travel. The trains are always late and there are no information boards to know which train is which. But there are some local people to help you (they understand the only srilankan announcements) to know which is your train - naturally for money, then give them a tip.

I regularly used this station when I live in SriLanka, again after almost 10 years I went to see any improvements there. Sad to say, rather than improvement, station lost it's charm further. Main culprits are the railway employees. They never mind anything, they are living in their world! Still old Canadian diesel locomotives pulling old compartments with packed commuters. Some new Indian power sets there, but they also not the twenty first century stuff! Toilets are worst, dirty rest rooms, even platforms and the over head bridges also filthy. Only good thing is still trains running, passengers using this station without hesitate anything! Need some good General Manager to improve the whole system. I can remember Mr.B.D. Rampala's period, when he worked as the General Manager of the CGR, what sort of improvements he made. Not only Colombo Fort Railway Station, but also whole SriLankan Railway need another Rampala!

Hard to find the ticket booth. Try to avoid the infocenter service, since they will try to sell you a full Sri Lanka tour at very high prices. The law prohibits to sell endstation to endstations tickets of you are just taking a part of the trip, but they did it anyway. So we paid 1000 rp for a 2 hours trip from Nanu Oya to Haputale... Try to buy form the ticket booth directly or ask your hotel for help. The station is right next to the Market and a 10 minute walk to the central bus station (on the opposite side of the street)

We travel the Exporail first class which is air conditioned and a good comfortable ride for cheap. The  tickets are best bought online and take the printout to the train station. Do not come last minute because the ticket counter can be crowded. The other best mode of travel within Colombo is the tuk tuk or as they call them 3 wheelers. This is cheapest but make sure they are a meter taxi and look at the meter once you get in to make sure they reset it . Keep an eye on the meter so you know your wait time and distance travelled. Some of the tuk tuk drivers will try to take advantage of foreigners. Do not always expect them to know the way or they may take you the long way around to make more money so always tell them to take you the shortest distance but also go to google and map that out so you know the roads to take and write them down. Most understand english but may not be able to communicate a whole lot..

The main railway station of the country, Fort Railway station is located close to the Pettah bus station (300metres) and connects well to every nook and corner of the country. The Fort station has a good Cloak (luggage) room service to store your luggage inside a huge box with a lock and key. Using the luggage room costs LKR 57 per day. It is quite cheap in case you wish to visit the city and not carry unnecessary luggage. The station is clean in general and well maintained. The trains need to improve as they all look quite old. You can sneak in and out without a ticket from the back side entrance. In case you book an Expo online ticket, make sure to go to the ticket reservation room and exchange that for an actual ticket printout. You need a train or platform ticket to enter the station. You will need to be early for the unreserved trains. It gets quite crowded and you will fight to get a seat. The third class coaches have an "E" on it and second class coaches have a "2" painted on them. Toilets are really bad and might make you vomit. Use the Foreign passengers toilet if it is available, it is available at the Kandy train station. Overall, a very crowded place.

Old British colonial railway station in its original form. issuing tickets , employees indifferent and don’t care attitude. busy and messy. Don’t think of using toilets. Rest rooms dirty. Canteen hopeless and surly unhygienic. Commuters unruly, no discipline at all when boarding and alighting from trains.

Firstly, the population that uses trains has probably not increased since the Brits first built this thing. It is so much fun to see the station in almost its original beauty and with so few people around (it seems no one uses the trains), it allows you to explore the place at your own pace taking in every little detail. Great place if you like going back in time every now and then :)

We imagine that the process of purchasing train tickets has not changed here for a century. It is kind of charming really but you must have patience and remember that it is best to plan ahead by a few days. Otherwise you may find that "you can't always get what you want" as the Stones put it but we did eventually find what we needed. First class tickets sell out rather quickly. especially for morning departures to popular places like Kandi.
The hub in Colombo for trains and the place can be very crowded with people travelling to many destinations in the country. Advanced reservations are required for special seating's.
If you are travelling to Kandy, take the second class carriage. You will get a seat, you can open the windows and an overall very enjoyable experience for seeing the sights and taking photos.

I have been here quite a number of times & I will be going gin the future too. It's not the place nor the mess that tests our patience but the staff that does not answer any question you raise. This goes on ...

Impossible to find where to go to book train tickets to Kandy unless someone from Colombo indicates you and expects a tip for his favor. It's a great place to feel inside the local life and the train experience is great in Sri Lanka when you can do the Colombo Kandy journey. Don't book 1st class tickets, they are just for tourists and the 2nd class is really not that bad and the trip will feel a lot more authentic.

This is the main Railway station in the capital Colombo.You can catch a train to any part of the Island.Srilanka has many good train routes.Like any major railway station this station is also surrounded by many food outlets.

Fort Railway Station is a major railway hub in Colombo City,  served by Sri Lanka Railways, with many inter-city and commuter trains go in and out daily. Fort Station is the main and the biggest rail gateway to central Colombo and also it is the terminus of most intercity trains in Srilanka. Fort Railway Station is located next to Colombo Fort and Pettah Marketand close to the meeting points of the A1 and A4 highways.Nearby also you would find the General Post Office and Central mail Exchange, Grand Oriental Hotel , adn Sampath Bank. The railways of Sri Lanka, first opened in Ceylon in 1864, trains terminated at Colombo Terminus Station, a now-retired station near Maradana. The earliest station to be called Fort Railway was a small station, built in 1877 when the Coast Line was built. This original station sat on the site of present-day Secretariat Halt just west of today's Fort Station. Visited this station as a part of Colombo City tour , on the way to Pettah Market, on early July 2014.
